p.span:
The SPEAKER ( Hon.
Tony Smith ) took the chair at 10:00, made an acknowledgement of country and read prayers.
DOCUMENTS
Parliament House
Presentation
The SPEAKER (10:01): I present the Presiding Officers' statement regarding the condition of Parliament House.
COMMITTEES
Petitions Committee
Report

Mr O'DOWD (Flynn—Deputy Nationals Whip) (10:01): I present the 16th report of the Petitions Committee for the 46th Parliament, comprising 119 petitions and 46 ministerial responses to petitions previously presented.

The past week has seen an unusually high number of visitors to our parliamentary e-petitions website, resulting in some intermittent timing-out problems. The performance of the website continues to be monitored and our IT support team are on hand to fix any problems if they arise. The committee would like to thank everyone who has tried to sign e-petitions online for their patience and eagerness to engage with petitioning. It's great to see that in these times of COVID-19, when many people may be feeling socially isolated without face-to-face interaction with their communities, online activities, such as e-petitioning, can bring like-minded people together in support of issues of mutual concern.

E-petitions can be easily shared to reach a wide audience. The House e-petitions system provides a unique URL for each certified e-petition, which can be shared via email or by posting it to social media platforms such as Twitter and Facebook. Petitioners can then just click on the link and enter their details to sign the petition. Analytics reports for the petitions website show that sharing a petition URL via social media is by far the most popular method of promoting an e-petition. The online community is therefore a very important avenue to promote and share petitions and to foster connections during a time that is different for us all and difficult for many.

While we hope that things can return to normal as soon as possible, and people are once again able to sign, by hand, a petition that they see at the local shops or at a community event, we, as the committee, are pleased that our e-petitions system is able to continue facilitating online interactions for like-minded communities with the parliament.
I look forward to further updating the House on the committee's progress.
PETITIONS
Mr O'DOWD (Flynn—Deputy Nationals Whip) (10:04): I present the following petitions:
Education

As a result of these unprecedented times, testing centres are closed and the students only option is to sit the LANTITE test online, for the foreseeable future. As the online version of LANTITE is run by an overseas company (U.S), spaces are limited and the majority of education students are being left without access or alternatives, forced out of their degree and are having their degree's withheld from them. This is stopping thousands of pre-service teachers from entering the profession, progressing in their education degrees, graduating, and registering. This will not only stop people from graduating and entering the field this year but also delay students in graduating for years to come.

These students have successfully completed the units in their degrees, as well as professional practise in the form of placements. Throughout degrees and placements, the importance of literacy and numeracy is highlighted, and students are graded on their abilities to successfully implement these areas in their teaching.

We implore you to support this notion of removing LANTITE. In doing so, you will be contributing and assisting Australia's economic return through this pandemic and recession as well as ensuring that our children continue to have access to quality teachers.
We therefore ask the House to abolish all education students LANTITE tests
From 7 citizens (EN1639)
Indigenous Heritage Protection

BHP want to destroy as many as 86 significant Aboriginal sites in the central Pilbara to expand their iron ore site. The continued destruction of sites important to Aboriginal Australians is seen as little more than cultural genocide.

The world condemned the recent destruction of the Juukan Gorge site by Rio Tinto, we can't let this keep happening. The Banjima people, traditional owners of the land, have told the WA Government this is a further significant cumulative loss to the cultural values of their people. We can stop this now, and in doing so send a clear message to the world about the kind of people we are.

BHP say on their own website "We respect the rights of Indigenous Peoples and acknowledge their right to maintain their culture, identity, traditions and customs." They can respect the "culture, identity, traditions and customs" of the Banjima people and not destroy some of the world's oldest archaeological sites.

We therefore ask the House to do the right thing by all Australians and stop the destruction of the Banjima people's cultural sites. We ask the House to remember they represent all Australians, including the most ancient continuous civilisation on Earth. And we ask the House to acknowledge the right of the Banjima people to maintain their culture, identity, traditions and customs. We ask you to preserve Australia's heritage.
From 18 citizens (EN1640)
JobKeeper Program
Actors and artists are our entertainment. It's what we watch on tv , it's the music we listen too. To think they're no worthy of support is rude
We therefore ask the House to make actors and arts able to get job keeper
From 2 citizens (EN1641)
National Anthem

In 2020 it is essential that all Australians come together to embrace all other Australians and find some peace together. One of the most important ways of doing that is recognising that Australians come from many places around the world, joining the first people of Australia in this country.
We therefore ask the House to make 'I am Australian' written by Bruce Woodley the national anthem.
From 21 citizens (EN1642)
Aboriginal Deaths in Custody

Since the Muirhead Royal Commission in 1987, there has been continued issues with black deaths in custody. Since 1991,432 Aboriginal people have died in custody. One death, of David Dungay in 2015, included the same final words as George Floyd; "I can't breathe". The technique used on Floyd and Dungay was also used on Robert Plasto-Lehner in 2009. The subsequent coronial inquest called the technique "fatally dangerous", making recommendations that - if distributed across all Australian jurisdictions - would have prevented Dungay's 2015 death and others in custody since. A 2018 study commissioned by then Indigenous Affairs Minister, Nigel Scullion, revealed that only 64 percent of recommendations by the Muirhead Commission were fully implemented. Imprisonment rates of Indigenous Australians has almost doubled from 1991-2018, and regular in-cell checks remained deficient in some jurisdictions.

We therefore ask the House to ask the Prime Minister and all relevant Ministers to commit to implementing in full the remaining recommendations of the Muirhead Royal Commission and spread the recommendations of the Plasto-Lehner Coronial inquest nationwide, including an immediate nationwide ban on the "prone position" technique in arrests and restraints - as well as a specific ongoing commitment for systemic change to prevent deaths in custody which should include a new database system to include coronial findings on deaths in custody and recommendations from all Australian jurisdictions. It should be distributed nationwide with the responses from state and federal authorities who are affected by the recommendations. Responses should be compulsory across all jurisdictions.
From 15 citizens (EN1643)
Environment

Mass damage and destruction of ecosystems (ECOCIDE), committed over decades and permitted by law, has led to global climate and ecological crisis. Treaties, agreements and civil lawsuits have all failed to prevent this. It is time to change the rules.

Amending the Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court to include ECOCIDE as a CRIME - alongside genocide, war crimes and crimes against humanity – can provide a simple, effective deterrent for those in positions of responsibility, enforceable within existing criminal justice systems.

We therefore ask the House to declare support for such an amendment, in the knowledge that many countries must stand together to put this law in place for the long-term protection of all life on Earth.
From 7 citizens (EN1644)
HomeBuilder
I would like to utter my terrible disappointment that Permanent residents and New Zealand Citizens have been excluded from this opportunity.
As a country, Australia is terribly reliant om immigrants to do many skilled jobs, and with skilled, I also mean many many Kiwis and other nationalities in the construction and other industries.
I find this discriminatory.
We therefore ask the House to include New Zealand Citizens and Permanent Residents in the home builders eligibility list.
From 14 citizens (EN1648)
Independent Commission Against Corruption

The citizens of Australia request that all members of the house support a bill to pass into legislation the establishment of a federal ICAC / independent anti-corruption commission so that the electorate is confident that members of parliament are being held accountable and corruption and conflicts of interest are identified independently and in a timely manner and appropriate action is taken.

We therefore ask the House to legislate that a federal ICAC be set up independently and with no party affiliations as a matter of urgency and demand that all sitting members support the bill to hold each other to a high standard. We request that the terms that this commission is established under investigate and expose corruption, provide advice and assistance in order to prevent corruption and educate citizens, whether in public service or otherwise, about corruption.
From 2367 citizens (EN1649)
Cryptocurrency
Currently, in Australia, "Cryptocurrency"; is currently not regulated by Legislation/Acts of Parliament.
Which means that Australian Law Enforcement Agencies IE ACORN/AFP/QPS ; currently cannot recover my stolen Money/"Cryptocurrency".

I Mr. Adrian Praljak, an admitted Australian Lawyer, in 2019 and in 2020, I have had; many thousands/or many hundreds of thousands of dollars or more; worth in "Cryptocurrency"; stolen from Me through both; 1) Online and 2) Through my Mobile phone; by using various Apps; which I downloaded from GooglePlay.
I have recently, successfully reported all offences committed against Me during both 2019 and in 2020 to both;
1) Australian Law Enforcement Authorities IE ACORN/AFP/QPS and
2) USA Law Enforcement Authorities IE The FBI and The FBI IC3.
We therefore ask the House to;
1) Act on regulating "Cryptocurrency" through creating; Urgent, new Legislation/Acts of Parliament
2) Give new Powers to all Australian Federal and State and Other Law Enforcement Agencies and other related Agencies to enforce new Legislation/Acts of Parliament Globally
3) Give new Powers to Australian Federal/State/Local Agencies; to work with Global, other Law Enforcement and other International Government Agencies

4) To please; 1) Provide Financial Compensation, Plus Financial Interest & any "Reimbursement" of all stolen; (Money in; AUD, USD, Fiat and "Cryptocurrency") and 2) Provide other Remedies to Mr. Adrian Praljak
From 4 citizens (EN1653)
Economy

It is noted that although cash is legal tender in Australia it is not unlawful for businesses to refuse to accept cash in payment for goods and services. The increasing trend in the number of businesses refusing to accept cash can prove extremely detrimental to those who do not possess the skill or ability to access means of electronic funds transfer. We believe that the trend toward a total cashless society is detrimental to many people's social and mental well-being and action needs to be taken to stop and reverse this trend.
We therefore ask the House to amend current or enact new legislation to make the refusal to accept cash unlawful.
From 34 citizens (EN1655)
Australian Parliament E-Petition Platform

Change.org has proven that a more accessible platform increases the opportunity for people to recognise a petition and sign it. There are hundreds of issues that remain unheard by government due to the fact many people think they are able to petition on change.org and still have an effect in parliament. The current platform is difficult and tedious to manoeuvre when compared to other petitioning platforms
We therefore ask the House to create a more open and accessible e-petitions platform that is easier shared and accessed, thereby again enabling the voice of the majority.
From 14 citizens (EN1656)
Higher Education

Education Minister Dan Tehan has announced an increase in fee costs for the following university degrees: humanities, law and economics. While also decreasing the fees in other 'job-ready' degrees such as medicine. Universities in Australia over the years have increased their business oriented focus. Education should NOT be focused solely on business, universities are NOT job factories. Australian research and education desperately need more funding, where can we get this funding from? Police, corrections and DEFENCE. Humanities, law and economics students are effectively now being asked to fund the cost of the Covid-19 pandemic. It is not their responsibility. This defunding along with the defunding of TAFE is designed to keep low socio-economic people out of university and is going to negatively impact Australia's potential for innovative research. University students are already struggling to pay their ever increasing HECS debts and this will increase the problem dramatically.

We therefore ask the House to remove any support for the Dan Tehan and the education department's initiative. We request that the budget is reconsidered with education as a priority, and to focus on refunding universities and TAFE. In doing so you will contribute to Australian's potential for innovative research, as well as helping people from low socio-economic backgrounds gain higher education.
From 13 citizens (EN1662)
E-Cigarettes

Banning the importation of nicotine based vaporizing liquid persecutes the poor, the disabled and the pensioners of Australia. These are the people who cannot afford to smoke cigarettes anymore. Many have smoked their entire lives and vaping nicotine is the only safe and affordable option for them. Banning the import, except by registered doctors and specially licensed pharmacists, of nicotine vaping liquid is unjust and anti-Australian. You are using COVID-19 restrictions to force through draconeon legislation and regulation changes through a barely functioning political system. Hang your heads in shame.
We therefore ask the House to REJECT the Proposal to put the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulation changes effective 1 July 2020.
From 3 citizens (EN1664)
Higher Education
The proposed reform to university fees based on a demand-based system is unjust and disadvantages higher education students, academics and experts.

Determining the price of higher education based on a long term economic strategy developed by the current government, rather than reflecting actual course costs, is an abuse of power and a violation of liberty and rights. The turbulent nature of the global economy over the past six months and the economic uncertainty currently faced by Australia should have adequately demonstrated to our government that long term economic strategy is not a sound basis for meaningful policy making in the current circumstances.

By targeting the disciplines of law and humanities, the government is actively discouraging and limiting access to degrees that encourage critical thinking, societal knowledge and government critique.

There are many other ways the government can encourage students to undertake degrees with high graduate-employment outcomes, such as investing resources into developing essential industries that ensure safe and well-paid long term employment for all Australians.
The proposed reforms will damage higher education as an industry, which is currently Australia's fourth largest export.

Australia's universities are both accessible and high quality, increasing prices and decreasing accessibility will hurt those currently employed in higher education, damaging the quality of our academics and field experts whilst suffocating innovation.
We therefore ask the House to prevent legislation passing that allows for university fee reforms based upon a demand based system.
From 4 citizens (EN1665)
E-Cigarettes

The E-cigarette has been around since roughly 2003 and as time has progressed the technology in E-cigarettes has evolved immensely yet we in Australia are still struggling to convince our Governments to make this legal !!

Lung Cancer has a rough annual death rate in Australia of 31 deaths Per 100,000 people per year although not all are caused by smoking cigarettes we can assume that at least 90% is caused by this horrid invention (cigarettes) in which the government makes millions in tax from the sales of cigarettes ! But we are yet to see a death from the use of an e-cigarette ! But many western countries have see the benefits for their people in legalizing E-cigarettes
The use of nicotine based oil in vapes should be legalised. Banning it as intended will only cause more domestic violence and crime and also another black market industry.
We therefore ask the House to rethink the banning of nicotine based vaping oil.
From 2 citizens (EN1667)
Australia Day
Australia Day should be a day in which we celebrate all Australians new and old.
The current date does not reflect the indigenous cultural history of this wonderful land, instead it marks a day when life for our first nation people changed forever.

'We are one, but we are many', lets celebrate the many, not the few and change the date to a new one, one in which we celebrate our differences and learn about our history and go some way to reconciling all people and all cultures.
We therefore ask the House to investigate changing the date to something more inclusive to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, the first peoples of this great land
From 6 citizens (EN1670)
National Anthem
The current Australian National Anthem does not reflect the indigenous cultural history of this wonderful country.
The line 'for we are young and free' is not acknowledging the traditional people who have looked after this great land for many thousands of years.

After a moving campaign on the ABC recently I propose that the anthem is changed to I am Australian by the Seekers for 'we are one, but we are many', lets celebrate the many, not the few and change the anthem to reflect Australians cultural diversity, an anthem in which we celebrate our differences and learn about our history and go some way to reconciling all people and all cultures.
We therefore ask the House to change the anthem to I am Australian by the Seekers.
From 5 citizens (EN1671)
Law Enforcement
We ask the House for a ROYAL COMMISSION INTO POLICE/LAW ENFORCEMENT in both; 1) State Police and 2) Federal Police in Australia.

I myself; Mr. Adrian Praljak, an admitted Australian Lawyer; I am a victim of both Queensland Police Service (QPS) and The Australian Federal Police (AFP)l, Unlawful conduct committed against Me and the false stagging of offences/Framed. This type of conduct is Unlawful and I now seek urgent Investigations and to hold those responsible to account under the Law and to receive significant financial compensation, Financial Interests, Payments and Remedies. These parties have played a significant, partial role in recently in 2020 making Me Medically Pernament Disabled, destroying my Life and my career as a Global Lawyer.
Both The QPS and The AFP have engaged in serious Conflict of Interest with Bond University Limited and other bad Parties in their Global Network.
Other people in the "Public"; are victims as well
We therefore ask the House to create an urgent ROYAL COMMISSION INTO POLICE/LAW ENFORCEMENT in both; 1) State Police and 2) Federal Police in Australia.
I seek urgent Investigations into QPS & AFP and other Parties, and to please now hold those responsible Parties; to account under the Law in Australia and to receive significant;
1) Financial Compensation
2) Financial Compounded Interests oveer many years and decades
3) Payments
4) other remedies
5) My Records Cleaned and Fixed
6) Written and Public Apologies from both The QPS and The AFP; and any other responsible Parties
Thank You
From 9 citizens (EN1672)
Health Care
This is a matter for house as it concerns all of australia

We therefore ask the House to examine the medical system for chronic pain sufferers .... Chronic pain is pain people have 24/7 because of this it's hard to work .sleep . social . They rely on government money something needs to be done you get 7 free medical a year. You do that in a month you need to see doctor's hospitals medication transport. Hydrotherapy pools. ........ Then to make things worse some doctors are crap. If you go hospital for pain relief the doctor could tell you to not go any more or be classed as addict ( yes it happen to me ) and doctors make comments like you have a sore back because your over weight not even ask why your their make comments straight away. .... As you see health system needs looking into only hand full of doctors are ignorant. The rest are good. ... Like elderly. Chronic pain sufferers. Need help .....
From 3 citizens (EN1673)
Arts

With the Creative Industry contributing $111.7 billion dollars to our economy, we feel we deserve more respect from the Government than being called a "small industry" full of "young people" not having "post-school qualifications". We typically employ slightly more Australians than mining does, and have tertiary education facilities such as AFTRS, NIDA, and Billy Blue, as well as specialised courses in universities around Australia. A great number of Federal and State politicians themselves have degrees in the Arts, so they cannot say that they do not have value.

With the recent increase of Arts degree costs, the Government will be forcing those wanting a formal education in the Arts and the Creative Industry to either take on a massive amount of debt, or drive people out of the industry entirely. This will have a massive effect on the Australian economy, and most likely harm our economic recovery from COVID-19. The economic contribution of the Creative Industry to Australia cannot be replaced, and therefore it is only fitting that the industry, and those of us who are in it, are given the respect we deserve by all levels of government.

We therefore ask the House to formally acknowledge the contribution the Creative Industry makes to this great country's economy; the diversity of age, gender, race, and education among those of us working in this industry; the cultural importance of the Creative Industry to the citizens of Australia; and the importance of the Creative Industry to Australia's image on the world stage.
From 6 citizens (EN1674)
Partner Visas

The current offshore partner visa processing system – the world's most expensive and slowest - separates Australians from partners, and children from parents, for up to and over two years. Offshore applicants pay the same fees as onshore applicants but cannot work, study, receive Medicare, nor reside in Australia like onshore applicants can. Instead they endure years of financial pressure from tourist visa fees and travel expenses from visiting their partners.

Offshore visa grants slowed during COVID-19 while onshore grants increased. Australian partners can travel safely and quarantine so should not be disadvantaged. Despite impacts on overseas processing centres, all partner visas are lodged online and require the same system of checks. The immigration department has the technology to equitably distribute the applications across all processing centres.
We therefore ask the House to reform the policy surrounding offshore partner visa applications to:
-distribute all partner visa applications equitably in a first come/first serve basis across the network of processing centres
-make transparent an applicant's position in the 'queue' and approximate waiting time
-ensure 'requests for further information' do not unfairly delay applications once further information is provided
-allow offshore applicants to be onshore when a decision is made as leaving poses unnecessary logistical, financial, and COVID-19 health risks to applicants currently visiting Australia
-make bridging visas available with the same rights as onshore applicants regarding work, study, and Medicare when the offshore applicant is in Australia
-remove partner visa caps and urgently process the partner visa backlog exceeding 90,000 applications
From 9336 citizens (EN1677)
Education

Hillsong and other pentecostal religions now being allowed into our schools a more dangerous problem arises. You as politicians are I believe precluded from doing anything against any religion but you are also empowered to make sure racism doesn't flourish or get taught in our country. Hillsong like other pentecostal religions have a primary belief that a supreme being or god created the Earth 6000 years ago. Teaching this to our children takes away 60,000 to 120,000 years of Abroginal culture. It is much more important to our children and to our society to have them understand how long Aboriginal culture has been around and how important it is to all of us. Allowing Hillsong and other pentecostal religions into our schools means they are promoting the denigration of Aboriginal culture. Protection of Aboriginal culture is much more important than religious fairy stories.

We therefore ask the House to cease funding schools that teach the belief a supreme being created the earth approximately 6000 years ago and to stop children attending places of worship that do the same.
From 5 citizens (EN1678)

The icebreaker RSV Aurora Australis served Australia's Antarctic Program for 30 years before being retired in March 2020. During this time she transported millions of tonnes of cargo and thousands of expeditioners. Important scientific research has been conducted on board. The Aurora Australis has been critical to the success of Australians in Antarctica.

The ship is viewed with great affection by all Australians but particularly the people of Hobart, her home port, where she is a familiar and well-loved sight. The prospect of a permanent ship museum has been well received there.

A new group, the Aurora Australis Foundation, seeks to purchase and preserve the ship in Hobart as a museum to Australian achievements in Antarctica. This museum would include accommodation, function and conference facilities and a maritime training centre.
However the owners P&O Maritime are seeking to sell the ship overseas, and a sale may be imminent.

The RSV Aurora Australis is the only Australian designed, built and crewed ship to serve the Antarctic Program, and the longest-serving ship to do so. She represents a significant part of Australia's Antarctic and maritime heritage and must not be lost to Australia and Australians.

We therefore ask the House to keep the RSV Aurora Australis in Australia by invoking the provisions of the Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Act 1986 pending a heritage assessment and feasibility study for an Australian Antarctic Museum in Hobart.
From 156 citizens (EN1679)
JobKeeper Payment

Our universities are being placed under enormous stress by COVID-19. Many students have temporarily dropped out or sought out experienced online learning providers to continue their education during this lockdown crisis.
To survive many universities have been forced to shed staff. Many of which are critical to a good learning experience.
I put forward the example of La Trobe University and their Bendigo regional campus. The Bendigo campus is necessary for regional Victoria to thrive and its survival has been placed under threat.
Jobkeeper for their casual staff would reduce the financial stress and allow for a better quality of education to come from their university.
Jobkeeper would also allow our academics to continue to do the research that our nation is proud of.

Any additional financial support to our university sector during this time will help our nation continue to maintain a high standard of education during this COVID-19 crisis and set our nation up for a better future beyond the pandemic.
Support for our universities is much needed in this time.
We therefore ask the House to provide jobkeeper to the casual staff in the university sector to allow them to continue to provide a high standard of education during and beyond this pandemic.
From 3 citizens (EN1681)
Welfare
Request House to create urgent ROYAL COMMISSION into Robodebt Centrelink.
I Mr. Adrian Praljak, a current admitted, Australian Lawyer and many thousands of other Australian vulnerable people; are victims from the serious, unlawful Robodebt Centrelink.

We seek to now urgently, hold those people accountable/responsible under Australian Law and other Global Laws/Legislation/Acts/ United Nations Charters; for this serious unlawful conduct which has caused serious Financial Loss and Mental and Physical damage to many thousands of people in Australia and Globally.
We therefore ask the House to;
1. Please create an urgent ROYAL COMMISSION into Robodebt Centrelink.

2. We seek to now urgently, hold those people accountable/responsible under Australian Law and other Global Laws/Legislation/Acts/ United Nations Charters; for this serious unlawful conduct which has caused serious Financial Loss and Mental and Physical damage to many thousands of people in Australia and Globally.

3. Please provide strong Financial Compensation, Financial Damages, Financial Compound Interest, Other Remedies, Apologies, Other Positive reasonable actions; to right these wrongs by The Australian Federal Government and Centrelink; to Mr. Adrian Praljak and other volunerable People in Australia and Globally
From 5 citizens (EN1683)
Consumer Rights

On Tuesday I ordered a product from a Queensland tech company. After realising a few hours later, that it would not fit my computer, I requested my order to be cancelled. The company cancelled my order, but will not refunded one cent of my money.
I can understand that a company can keep 'some' money if a customer changes their mind, but not 100% of the person's money: how the Australian 'law' stands at this point.
This needs to change so that a customer loses no more than 80% of the money paid for the product. I have lost $200. I have lost confidence in Australian businesses. This extends recession.

We therefore ask the House to amend Consumer Law and any other relevant law so that the customer is left no more than 80% out of pocket if they change their mind and the product has not been sent from the factory.
Unless, of course, the politicians of Australia are happy that Australian consumers can lose all of their money to a business in return for nothing to the consumer - tantamount to theft.
That in my mind is illegal and those responsible, including law makers, are no better than criminals stealing money from customers bank accounts.
No goods and no service rendered should entitle the purchaser to at least some (e.g. 80%) of their money guaranteed back - not the forfeit of the entire amount to unscrupulous businesses.
Please amend this outdated law that amounts to theft. Thank you.
From 3 citizens (EN1686)
Royal Commissions: Disability Services
I, Mr. Adrian Praljak, an Australian, Admitted Lawyer, am respectfully requesting the House to please;
"Reform" All Current and Future;
"Royal Commissions"; to now; ASAP accommodate people who are "Disabled"; with all types of Disabilities.
The same as with the current;

"Royal Commission into Violence, Abuse, Neglect and Exploitation of People with Disability"; they provide a variety of; "Different"; Fair "Processes" and reasonable "Accommodations" to all; "Disabled People'.

So that they too; can lodge their; Formal "Submissions" To The Royal Commission; and have a "Voice" about various Issues/Cases; and Attend Private Sessions of a Royal Commission; In Person/By Phone/By Other uses of Modern Technology.
We therefore ask the House to;

1) "Reform" ASAP; all current and future; Royal Commissions; to accommodate people who are; "Disabled" (Taking into account and providing fair; "Processes" and making; "Reasonable Accommodations" in their "Submissions Processes/Attending In-Person or through the use of Modern Technology/Private Sessions of The Royal Commission/Or being Involved in the Different sections of a Royal Commission.

2) Putting these "Safeguards" in place for All Royal Commissions and having a Federal Commission to periodically monitor that these Safeguards are being followed and Prosecuting offenders; for breaching such Safeguards.

3) The United Nations has a variety of; Disability/Human Rights/ other Charters; which Australia is a party to. Educating the people/and Filing any breaches/complaints; of people who experience any type of discrimination; by not being able to participate in any Royal Commission; because they are Disabled physically or Intellectualy or both; such as Myself.
From 2 citizens (EN1689)
Employment
The employees of 'Customer Service' are not employed overseas.
It is going to be a standard structure in the operation of Government and Businesses, supporting redevelopment of Australia.

We therefore ask the House to make it a standard requirement of Company's or Government's office; to demand their structure requires 'Customer Services' be employed in Australia and not overseas. This demonstrates their support for redevelopment of Australian living.
From 15 citizens (EN1692)
Live Animal Exports

As the starter of an e petition with change.org that has 376,581 signatures and was denied in the senate, I want the Australian parliament to take this seriously. The frozen export sector is worth far more money to Australia than Live Export.
Apart from that animal abuse is an obvious reason to end Live Animal Exports. What else is shipped alongside those animals, DRUGS? GUNS? PEOPLE?.
Live Animal Export is full of corruption and has to end! Any decent government official knows this. CEASE LIVE ANIMAL TRADE FROM AUSTRALIA.
We therefore ask the House too everything in their powers to bring an end the corrupt and miserable excuse for animal abuse - Live Export!
From 220 citizens (EN1696)
Citizenship

This is a request to restart the citizenship tests/interviews or a change in this process. Many people on PR/Visa, who are eligible for citizenship, have lost their jobs in this difficult time. While it is not very urgent or an essential service, had they received citizenship, they would have applied to Govt. jobs or went back to college with HECS and come out equipped with better skills to help economy. Most of the states now have allowed moderate gatherings in line with medical officer's advice. Given that majority of states, barring Victoria, has resumed near normal life, resumption of test/interview will be a great relief to all the pending candidates.
We therefore ask the House to consider the below alternatives:

1) In States where large gathering are allowed, restart the test and not wait for all the states to return to same normal situation. Allow test with social distancing and ask mandatory usage of masks/gloves. Computer be equipped with wipes to clean the keyboard/monitor before/after tests. During interview, a screen can be placed between candidate and officer.
2) One option can be developing an app based test on user mobile at testing centre. Department can keep spare mobiles in case someone has issue with the mobile.
3) Another option can allow test be taken at approved private vendors/universities. Document verification can be done at Centrelink/Police station/Post Office/Driving license authority.
4) Alternatively, test/interview can be waived off with special ministerial permissions. This will make Australian citizenship process similar to NZ process.
From 372 citizens (EN1697)
COVID-19: International Travel
The Federal Government's decision to close Australia's borders to travel in and out of the country except under certain (not clearly defined) circumstances requires review.
We therefore ask the House to seek review and clarification from the Federal Government on:
1) Restrictions of the freedom of movement of residents to travel internationally as part of the government's response to COVID-19, including
a) the specific triggers for this decision,
b) reasons for the extension of same decision until the end of 2020, and
c) a review of the triggers for this decision in the light of current developments and geographical differences of the COVID-19 pandemic
d) inflexibility of this decision to account for a continually evolving situation and differences on geographical distribution of COVID-19 cases; and
e) presenting alternatives to current approach for Debate and Consultation to the appropriate parliamentary body.
2) Review of and clear guidelines for travel exemptions.
3) Review of and presentation of alternative options for compulsory 14-day isolation quarantine in a hotel room upon entry into Australia (i.e. technology tracking via Apps etc).
4) Appropriateness of border closures and travel restrictions in the light of
a) the COVID-19 pandemic as it continually evolves, other countries (i.e. EU) are re-opening and considering "safe corridors" and safe countries versus risk countries; and
b) the economic impact (with AUD loss and employment figures) on inter alia the airline and tourism industries

From 512 citizens (EN1698)
Taxation

Under the current legislation, businesses are being dis/advantaged in access to the government's Cash Flow Boost stimulus response to COVID-19 based on the way in which they lodge their Business Activity Statements with The ATO.

The legislation requires a business must have made a lodgement showing 'taxable supply' prior to March 12th in order to access the Cash Flow Boost. This means a business created on or after Jan 1st 2020 which files their BAS quarterly is automatically deemed ineligible. Equally, a business formed on or after 1 July 2019 which files their BAS Annually is automatically deemed ineligible.
If those same businesses had filed their BAS lodgements on a monthly basis, they would be deemed eligible.

Two identical businesses with different BAS lodgement periods receive vastly different outcomes. The red tape of when a business lodges its business activity statement is creating unequal support under the current legislation.
We therefore ask the House to amend the current legislation to waive the Business Activity Statement lodgement requirement for those businesses that were created on or after:
• 1 July 2019 and lodge their Business Activity Statement annually
• 1 January 2020 and lodge their Business Activity Statement quarterly
This action would remove discrimination against businesses based on the way in which they complete their Business Activity Statements.

From 4 citizens (EN1704)
COVID-19: International Travel

A multitude of issues related to the global pandemic have made it difficult and complex for Australians and permanent residents and their families to return to Australia. These difficulties have been further complicated by recent restrictions placed on incoming flights and the State Governments' push to charge Australians for a mandated quarantine period. Each returning Australian's case is different, but many are facing financial, emotional, and mental hardship which is further exacerbated by the Federal and State Governments' restrictions. Furthermore, the language used by both Government and the media is leading to a growing resentment towards returning Australians within the community and are fearful of being further vilified though we have done nothing wrong.

We therefore ask the House to speak on behalf of returning Australians to inquire into the harshness of the travel restrictions and the cost of quarantine that is being unfairly put on our shoulders. We seek to have flight restrictions lifted so that we can return home and be reunited with our loved ones. We fully support the quarantine process and see its benefit, but ask that the cost not be shifted to us as many of us are already stretched beyond our means. Furthermore, we seek a compassionate response from members of Government and the media as we undertake the difficult process of returning to our families and the country that we love. From 10622 citizens (EN1710)
Environment

Cairns Regional Council is the latest government authority to interfere with the camps of Australia's flying-foxes, in this case the endangered Spectacled Flying-fox at the Cairns CBD Library roost, located at 151 Abbott Street. This camp harboured more than 10% of the remaining national population and has been disrupted many times by human activities. Flying-foxes are crucial to the good health of ecosystems and must be recognised as valid and valued residents. They are key to the pollination of plants and the dispersal of fruit; crucial for vegetation to thrive. Yet their populations continue to plummet and government authorities seem unable to do more than 'manage' the concerns of the few who fail to understand the inherent value of these amazing animals. The laws designed to protect flying-foxes are failing, especially in their permitting the harassment of the Spectacled Flying-fox (Cairns Regional Council claims to have received approval from the Federal Department of Agriculture, Water and the Environment (DAWE) to implement deterrent measures to disperse and permanently relocate the camp notwithstanding numerous historical examples of the flying-foxes becoming distressed and unpredictable in their movements after being disturbed).

We therefore ask the House to cease permitting these disturbances to flying-fox camps across Australia and to review the EPBC Act in light of plummeting populations. We also ask for community education programs to highlight the important role of flying-foxes in our ecosystems.

COVID-19: International Travel

We ask the House to review the travel ban that prevents Australians or permanent residents to leave the country until further notice. According to the Department of Home Affairs web-page, people can apply for an exemption at least 4 weeks, but not more than 3 months before their planned travel.

Australian is the only liberal democracy that has imposed such a strict limitation of free movement, infringing a basic human right. There is no public health necessity to ban people from leaving the country if they need to do so, and they are willing to bear the cost involved in the process, including mandated quarantine and Covid test at their own expenses upon return. This is a matter of great concern that affects a large proportion of Australians who have family overseas.

The requirements make impossible to travel in case of compassionate reasons or a family emergency when people do not have the luxury to apply for an exemption 4 weeks in advance, nor have the time to collect required documents and translate them into English if required. The screening process is not transparent and response time appears to vary enormously.

We therefore ask the House to review the travel ban, establishing a fast track procedure allowing to travel for compassionate reasons and family emergencies. For instance, by replacing the current requirements with a statutory declaration in which applicants state the urgent need for travelling and accept bearing all the risks and costs (e.g. quarantine) associated with overseas travelling.

From 105 citizens (EN1786)
COVID-19: International Travel
In March 2020, Australia banned its citizens from leaving their country as a preventative measure to protect public health during the SARS-CoV-2 pandemic.

The primary goal of preventing Australian citizens from leaving the country has been articulated as a measure to prevent the spread of SARS-CoV-2 within Australia. At the time of writing, Australia has recorded over 22,000 confirmed cases of the virus, with almost all of these infections occurring domestically.
It is therefore clear that the SARS-Covid-2 virus is already well established within the borders of Australia, and that citizens may be more likely to be infected within Australia than abroad.

Further, if the government of Australia has banned its citizens from leaving their country as an instrument to protect the country from a viral pandemic, the only mechanism for this claim to be true and proportionate would be evidence that Australian citizens, and only Australian citizens, possess a unique ability to transmit SARS-CoV-2 from thousands of kilometres away. No such evidence has been provided.

This petition does not challenge the real and present danger of the SARS-CoV-2 pandemic to public health, though it does argue that preventing Australian citizens from leaving the country is not a proportionate or effective response, and is causing real harm to citizens who have supposedly 'non-essential' reasons to travel abroad, such as work and family.
We therefore ask the House to do all within its power to reverse the ban placed on Australian citizens exiting the country.

From 30604 citizens (EN1801)
Australian Constitution

Plebiscites and referendums allow Australians to have a direct say on matters of importance to our nation. The last legally binding plebiscite was held in 1977, and the last referendum was held in 1999. During the 1900s, Australia held three plebiscites and 19 referendums where 47 direct questions were asked for a direct "yes" or "no" vote from Australians. These were a standard feature of our democratic landscape during the 1900s. Given that Australians born after 1980 have never participated in a plebiscite or referendum, and given the 'sunk' costs every Federal Election already incurs, it is prudent to give Australians the opportunity to provide a direct answer on matters of importance to our nation. Since 2000, Australians have gone to the Federal Elections seven times — this is a lost opportunity for direct answers to complex questions. Providing a plebiscite or a referendum at every Federal Election would give Australians a direct voice that moves beyond political factions. This will increase trust in our civic institutions and governance processes. Providing a plebiscite or a referendum at every Federal Election would give Australians another avenue of direct representation at the national level, to help shape Australia progressing forwards, and to allow our voices to be heard clearly on matters of importance.

We therefore ask the House to include a plebiscite or a referendum at every Federal Election to save time and money, and to allow our voices to be heard clearly and directly on matters of importance to all Australians.
From 26 citizens (EN1802)
COVID-19: Vaccine

Australians have inalienable human rights relating to self-determination and autonomy, as described by treaties including the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. Mandatory vaccinations actively discriminate against those who seek to exercise their inalienable human rights. Australians are entitled to deny their consent to have their bodies violated by a mandatory COVID-19 vaccination.

Hundreds of medical professionals globally have expressed concerns over the safety and effectiveness of a COVID-19 vaccine. Proposed vaccines to date have involved DNA modification. This is a method which has not been used in any previous human vaccinations and its effects on the human body are largely unknown.

No long term testing has been conducted on the effects of the COVID-19 vaccine distributed to Australians. Disclosure of the vaccine's ingredients, or any known side effects, has not been made public.

We propose that a vaccine injury compensation scheme is introduced in Australia. This will ensure that citizens are able to hold the Commonwealth accountable for detriment they may suffer as a result of receiving a vaccination. We remind the House that it is the duty of this Government, acting on behalf of the Commonwealth, to protect the rights, safety and well-being of its citizens.

We therefore ask the House to make a COVID-19 vaccination in Australia voluntary, rather than mandatory. We ask that full disclosure of the vaccine's ingredients and side effects are made publicly available as soon as practicable. Further, we ask that a vaccine injury compensation scheme is introduced in Australia.

This petition of citizens of Australia and other countries draws to the attention of the House that 30 years after the 1987 Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody brought down its findings at least 437 more deaths have occurred. These have been mostly linked to high incarceration rates, although to discrimination in some cases. A key 2018 assessment by the Australian Law Reform Commission entitled 'Pathways to Justice' made 35 recommendations to achieve more substantive equality before the law for Indigenous Australians and reduce incarceration rates. These address ingrained disadvantages, and include reforms to out-of-home care, not being jailed for unpaid fines, abolishing mandatory sentencing, and instituting justice reinvestment. Policing should be fair and discretionary, and discrimination complaints properly and independently investigated. We welcome the new National Agreement on Closing the Gap, its formal Partnership with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples, and its having reduction of overrepresentation in the criminal justice and child protection systems as targets. In this regard we believe an overdue reform is raising the age of criminal responsibility in Australia to 14 years, so that young people are given access to the support services they need rather than being locked up.

We therefore ask the House to: address the issues around Indigenous incarceration and Aboriginal deaths in custody to ensure that effective and lasting changes are made to social and justice systems across Australia that will improve the lives and communities of Aboriginal people and provide substantive equality.
From 7 citizens (PN0485)
Petitions received.
PETITIONS
Responses
Mr O'DOWD (Flynn—Deputy Nationals Whip) (10:04): I present the following ministerial responses to petitions previously presented:
Welfare
Dear Chair

Thank you for your letter of 9 April 2020 regarding Petition Number EN1268 which seeks the temporary suspension of the Australian Government's international development program to enable funding to be redirected towards domestic priorities.

These are extraordinary times for Australia. The recent drought, bushfires, and now the COVID-19 pandemic, have all impacted heavily on Australian communities. I assure the signatories to this petition that keeping Australia and Australians safe continues to be the Government's highest priority.

Our international development program is targeted, effective and necessary. Australia benefits when neighbouring countries are secure, stable, well governed and able to achieve strong and sustainable economic growth. The growth and stability of our region has provided the foundations for our own security and prosperity over recent decades.

Working with our regional partners to combat the spread of COVID-19 and manage the economic fallout is an important part of protecting Australia and Australians. How our region responds to, and recovers from, the pandemic directly affects Australia's national interests. If transmission rates are not controlled, our own health security could be compromised. If the region does not recover and open up, our own economic recovery could be affected, including the one in five Australian jobs that depend on trade. Partnerships for Recovery: Australia's COVID-19 Development Response Strategy sets out how the development program will contribute to a stable, prosperous and resilient region in the wake of COVID-19.

Australia's international development program does not take away from the assistance the Government makes available to support those in Australia affected by the recent bushfires or financial hardship as a result of COVID-19. The Australian Government's official development assistance (ODA) represented less than one per cent of the total 2019-20
Budget released by the Government on 2 April 2019. We have the resources to help people here in Australia as well as overseas.
I thank the signatories for drawing this important issue to the Parliament's attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for International Development and the Pacific, Mr Hawke
COVID 19: Economy
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence, originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petition Ministerial Referral (EN1417). Your correspondence has been referred to me as I have responsibility for this matter.

The Morrison Government appreciates the critical role of small business and family enterprise in supporting the economy as well as the unprecedented challenges and financial burden posed by the bushfires of 2019-20 and then the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020.

The Government notes the announcement on 8 July 2020 by the Australian Banking Association on the continued 'phase two' support by banks for customers on repayment deferrals. In summary, where borrowers can pay in fill, then they will be required to restart paying at the end of their deferral period. Where borrowers can partially pay, then they will have their loans restructured or failing that deferred again. Where borrowers cannot pay, then they will be assisted through their bank's financial hardship process. While repayment deferrals can assist some borrowers from a cash flow perspective, interest continues to accrue during the deferral period.

Petition number EN1417 calls for the House of Representatives to 'suspend rent, business loan, mortgage and credit card repayments in Australia immediately'. The Government not does support the specific course of action set out in the petition for the following reasons:

While it is the case that the banking system is well capitalised and in a strong liquidity position, broad-based suspension of repayments, particularly without capitalisation of interest, would materially impact the profitability, sustainability and stability of the banking sector. This would in turn negatively impact the ability of banks to continue to lend to support economic activity and the ability of banks to pay dividends to shareholders (which include many Australians, both directly and indirectly through superannuation).

The Government considers decisions about repayment deferrals are commercial decisions for financial institutions. Suspension of contractually-agreed loan repayments by the Parliament of Australia — even assuming such suspension were constitutional — would represent a substantial interference with pre-existing contractual arrangements of lenders.

The Morrison Government's economic response to COV1D-19 continues to provide temporary and timely support to affected workers, businesses and the broader community, and has kept Australians in jobs, and businesses in business. The Government is supporting the re-opening of the economy and getting people back into jobs, while assisting those still affected by health restrictions and protecting against further spread of the virus. It is vital to get businesses back open, enable Australians to go back to work and ensure consumers and businesses have the confidence to return to normal activities as far as possible.
Central to the Government's response package is the support provided for businesses and employers. Key measures include:

The JobKeeper Payment is helping keep businesses in business and Australians in jobs. It supports businesses significantly impacted by COVID-19 to cover the costs of their employees' wages, so more Australians can retain their jobs and continue to earn an income. On 21 July 2020, the Government announced the JobKeeper Payment will be extended to provide continued support until 28 March 2021, with the payment targeted to those businesses that continue to be most significantly affected by the economic downturn.

The Government is supporting small and medium-sized businesses and not-for-profit employers by providing temporary cash flow support to keep people in jobs and stay in business. Eligible entities automatically receive payments of between $20,000 and $100,000 for the March to September 2020 reporting periods upon lodgement of relevant activity statements. These payments will help businesses' and not-for-profits' cash flow so they can keep operating, pay their rent, electricity and other bills, and retain staff.

The Government has put in place temporary relief for financially-distressed businesses that have been impacted by the COV1D-19 pandemic relating to insolvency and other targeted relief to facilitate the continuation of business.

In addition to the cash flow support, the Government is backing businesses to invest by increasing the instant asset write-off threshold to $150,000 (up from $30,000) and expanding access to include businesses with aggregated annual turnover of less than $500 million (up from $50 million).
I trust this information will be of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Superannuation, Financial Services and Financial Technology, Senator Hume
COVID-19: Migration
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your email dated 15 June 2020, concerning petition EN1434 to the House of Representatives, which relates to support for temporary visa holders affected by COVID-19. I regret the delay in responding.
As part of its national response to the COVID-19 crisis, the Government has introduced a range of measures to support the Australian community.

Australia's social security system is a non-contributory, residence-based system, designed primarily to support Australian citizens and permanent residents. For this reason, most temporary visa holders, including those on student, work and most bridging visas, do not have access to Australian social security payments.

Some temporary visa holders, including those on temporary partner visas, may be able to access Special Benefit if they face significant financial hardship. Special Benefit is paid at the same rate as the JobSeeker Payment.

In addition, the Government has allowed individuals, including temporary visa holders, who are in financial stress due to COVID-19 to access their superannuation. Eligible temporary visa holders were able to access up to $10,000 of their superannuation before 1 July 2020.

The Government has also provided a $200 million boost to community services, which will expand support to vulnerable people including assistance for paying bills and buying other essentials, such as food, clothing and petrol. This includes funding for the Australian Red Cross to deliver emergency relief and some casework support to temporary visa holders facing significant vulnerabilities. There are no residency restrictions to access existing or expanded emergency relief services.
The Government is closely monitoring the health, economic and social impacts of COVID-19 and will continue to take a measured approach as the situation changes.
Thank you again for raising this petition with me. I trust the information provided will be of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Families and Social Services, Senator Ruston

Pensions and Benefits
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your email dated 15 June 2020, regarding Petition EN1440, which concerns JobSeeker Payment. I regret the delay in responding.

The COVID-19 pandemic represents a significant challenge for our community and economy. The Government is acting decisively in the national interest to support households and businesses and address the significant economic consequences of coronavirus, providing $289 billion worth of support to 2023-24.

The petitioner suggests the Government should provide a wage subsidy to employers rather than support through welfare payments. The Government has introduced the JobKeeper Payment to help businesses impacted by the coronavirus to continue paying their employees. The JobKeeper Payment, which is currently paid at $1,500 a fortnight, has been extended past its original end date of 27 September 2020 but will be paid at reduced tiered rates. For more information, visit www.treasury.gov.au/coronavirus/jobkeeper/extension.

The Government's focus now is on getting Australians through the coronavirus and the economic consequences of the pandemic. The Government has temporarily supercharged the social security safety net to assist Australians doing it tough throughout the coronavirus outbreak, which has included the Coronavirus Supplement, expanding eligibility for income support payments, and two rounds of $750 Economic Stimulus Payments to eligible recipients.

The Government is extending the temporary Coronavirus Supplement to 31 December 2020 and adjusting the rate to $250 a fortnight from 25 September 2020 to reflect the gradually improving economic and labour market conditions. The Government is also changing the JobSeeker Payment and Youth Allowance (other) income tests to improve incentives for individuals to re-enter the workforce or take on additional work as the economy recovers.
Thank you for raising this matter with me.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Families and Social Services, Senator Ruston
5G Technology
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your email, dated 15 June 2020, on behalf of the Petitions Committee concerning Petition EN1487 which requests a moratorium on the roll-out of 5th generation (5G) mobile technology.

The Morrison Government's policy is that all people in Australia should be able to access modern telecommunications services regardless of where they live or do business. Often, this means new telecommunications facilities need to be installed to provide those services.

Decisions about network infrastructure requirements and timing of these new installations are commercial matters for carriers. When proposing to install new infrastructure, carriers can either use local planning frameworks, or the Commonwealth planning framework under the Telecommunications Act 1997 for eligible equipment. These requirements also apply to 5G network equipment.

The Government acknowledges that there is community interest in being satisfied that rigorous safety standards are in place to guard against the risk of over exposure to EME from mobile phone base stations. The Government strictly regulates EME emissions, to protect the health and safety of the public while allowing the community to benefit from modern telecommunications.

The Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency (ARPANSA) provides expert advice on radiation protection and nuclear safety matters to the Government. In order to provide the best advice on the protection of the Australian public from the effects of radiation, ARPANSA undertakes its own research and reviews the relevant scientific research. This includes research and reviews of exposure to EME emissions from mobile telecommunications sources. ARPANSA also publishes the Radiation Protection Standard for Maximum Exposure Levels to Radiofrequency Fields - 3 kHz to 300 GHz ('ARPANSA Standard') which sets limits for EME exposure.
The Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA) adopts those limits as part of its regulatory requirements for the telecommunications sector.

The effects of EME exposure have been the subject of extensive and rigorous scientific study around the world for many decades. ARPANSA maintains continual oversight of emerging research into the potential health effects of EME emissions. It also consults with the world's peak health bodies, such as the World Health Organization (WHO) and the International Commission on Non-Ionizing Radiation Protection (ICNIRP), so that Australia can contribute to and benefit from the best international research and guidance on this matter. Based on the best available research, ARPANSA and other leading health authorities advise that there are no known health effects from EME at levels below the ARPANSA Standard.

ICNIRP has recently released a review of its international guidance, based on significant consultation and scientific review. ARPANSA advises that the level of protection provided by Australia's current standard is comparable to that provided by the new ICNIRP guidelines, however ARPANSA will be revising Australia's standard to ensure the scientific evidence, measurements and modelling in the new ICNIRP guidelines are addressed in the Australian Standard. I understand that the majority of countries apply the ICNIRP guidelines as a basis for its regulatory requirements.

On 13 September 2019, I asked the Committee to inquire into and report on the deployment, adoption and application of 5G in Australia. The Committee has released its report and the Government will consider its findings and respond in due course. I understand that the Committee received many submissions and considered evidence from a range of parties, and ultimately has been assured that 5G is safe.

In December last year, I also announced a $9 million package over four years to provide for more funding for research into EME from telecommunications facilities and for more communications activities about the safety and regulation of EME. While decades of research indicates there are no known harmful effects from low levels of EME used for telecommunications, the Government recognises the need to continue research, particularly for emerging technologies. With this funding, ARPANSA will deliver the research program previously funded by the National Health and Medical Research Council. Outcomes of this research will be included in clearer, more accessible information for the public about EME from telecommunications facilities.
I hope the information in this letter is of some help.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Cyber Safety and the Arts, Mr Fletcher
5G Technology
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your email, dated 15 June 2020, on behalf of the Petitions Committee concerning Petition EN1490 which requests a moratorium on the roll-out of 5th generation (5G) mobile technology.

The Morrison Government's policy is that all people in Australia should be able to access modem telecommunications services regardless of where they live or do business. Often, this means new telecommunications facilities need to be installed to provide those services.

Decisions about network infrastructure requirements and timing of these new installations are commercial matters for carriers. When proposing to install new infrastructure, carriers can either use local planning frameworks, or the Commonwealth planning framework under the Telecommunications Act 1997 for eligible equipment. These requirements also apply to 50 network equipment.

The Government acknowledges that there is community interest in being satisfied that rigorous safety standards are in place to guard against the risk of over exposure to EME from mobile phone base stations. The Government strictly regulates EME emissions, to protect the health and safety of the public while allowing the community to benefit from modem telecommunications.

The Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency (ARPANSA) provides expert advice on radiation protection and nuclear safety matters to the Government. In order to provide the best advice on the protection of the Australian public from the effects of radiation, ARPANSA undertakes its own research and reviews the relevant scientific research. This includes research and reviews of exposure to EME emissions from mobile telecommunications sources. ARPANSA also publishes the Radiation Protection Standard for Maximum Exposure Levels to Radiofrequency Fields - 3 kHz to 300 GHz ('ARPANSA Standard') which sets limits for EME exposure.

The Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA) adopts those limits as part of its regulatory requirements for the telecommunications sector. The effects of EME exposure have been the subject of extensive and rigorous scientific study around the world for many decades. ARPANSA maintains continual oversight of emerging research into the potential health effects of EME emissions. It also consults with the world's peak health bodies, such as the World Health Organization (WHO) and the International Commission on Non-Ionizing Radiation Protection (ICNIRP), so that Australia can contribute to and benefit from the best international research and guidance on this matter. Based on the best available research, ARPANSA and other leading health authorities advise that there are no known health effects from EME at levels below the ARPANSA Standard.

ICNIRP has recently released a review of its international guidance, based on significant consultation and scientific review. ARPANSA advises that the level of protection provided by Australia's current standard is comparable to that provided by the new ICNIRP guidelines, however ARPANSA will be revising Australia's standard to ensure the scientific evidence, measurements and modelling in the new ICNIRP guidelines are addressed in the Australian Standard. I understand that the majority of countries apply the ICNIRP guidelines as a basis for its regulatory requirements.

On 13 September 2019, I asked the Committee to inquire into and report on the deployment, adoption and application of 5G in Australia. The Committee has released its report and the Government will consider its findings and respond in due course. I understand that the Committee received many submissions and considered evidence from a range of parties, and ultimately has been assured that 5G is safe.

In December last year. I also announced a $9 million package over four years to provide for more funding for research into EME from telecommunications facilities and for more communications activities about the safety and regulation of EME. While decades of research indicates there are no known harmful effects from low levels of EME used for telecommunications, the Government recognises the need to continue research, particularly for emerging technologies. With this funding, ARPANSA will deliver the research program previously funded by the National Health and Medical Research Council. Outcomes of this research will be included in clearer, more accessible information for the public about EME from telecommunications facilities.
I hope the information in this letter is of some help.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Cyber Safety and the Arts, Mr Fletcher

5G Technology
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your email, dated 15 June 2020, on behalf of the Petitions Committee concerning Petition EN1504 which requests a moratorium on the roll-out of 5th generation (5G) mobile technology.

The Morrison Government's policy is that all people in Australia should be able to access modern telecommunications services regardless of where they live or do business. Often, this means new telecommunications facilities need to be installed to provide those services.

Decisions about network infrastructure requirements and timing of these new installations are commercial matters for carriers. When proposing to install new infrastructure, carriers can either use local planning frameworks, or the Commonwealth planning framework under the Telecommunications Act 1997 for eligible equipment. These requirements also apply to 5G network equipment.

The Government acknowledges that there is community interest in being satisfied that rigorous safety standards are in place to guard against the risk of over exposure to EME from mobile phone base stations. The Government strictly regulates EME emissions, to protect the health and safety of the public while allowing the community to benefit from modern telecommunications.

The Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency (ARPANSA) provides expert advice on radiation protection and nuclear safety matters to the Australian Government. In order to provide the best advice on the protection of the Australian public from the effects of radiation, ARPANSA undertakes its own research and reviews the relevant scientific research. This includes research and reviews of exposure to EME emissions from mobile telecommunications sources. ARPANSA also publishes the Radiation Protection Standard for Maximum Exposure Levels to Radiofrequency Fields - 3 kHz to 300 GHz (ARPANSA Standard') which sets limits for EME exposure.
The Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA) adopts those limits as part of its regulatory requirements for the telecommunications sector.

ARPANSA's advice is that after many decades of research, it is well established that exposure to EME at very high power levels can cause excessive heating of the human body. The limits of the ARPANSA Standard are set well below the level at which harm may occur. The recommendation of further research for frequencies above 6 GHz is related to being more precise on the level where thermal stress occurs which is relevant to potential occupational exposures close to the limit of the standard. Exposure to EME from telecommunications sources, like 5G, is much lower than the limits of the standard and there are no established health effects. The new guidance from ICNIRP provides more precise limits for thermal stress, particularly for frequencies above 6 GHz.

ICNIRP has recently released a review of its international guidance, based on significant consultation and scientific review. ARPANSA advises that the level of protection provided by Australia's current standard is comparable to that provided by the new ICNIRP guidelines, however ARPANSA will be revising Australia's standard to ensure the scientific evidence, measurements and modelling in the new ICNIRP guidelines are addressed in the Australian Standard. I understand that the majority of countries apply the ICNIRP guidelines as a basis for its regulatory requirements.

On 13 September 2019, I asked the Committee to inquire into and report on the deployment, adoption and application of 5G in Australia. The Committee has released its report and the Government will consider its findings and respond in due course. I understand that the Committee received many submissions and considered evidence from a range of parties, and ultimately has been assured that 5G is safe.

In December last year, I also announced a $9 million package over four years to provide for more funding for research into EME from telecommunications facilities and for more communications activities about the safety and regulation of EME. While decades of research indicates there are no known harmful effects from low levels of EME used for telecommunications, the Government recognises the need to continue research, particularly for emerging technologies. With this funding, ARPANSA will deliver the research program previously funded by the National Health and Medical Research Council. Outcomes of this research will be included in clearer, more accessible information for the public about EME from telecommunications facilities.
I hope the information in this letter is of some help. Yours sincerely
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Cyber Safety and the Arts, Mr Fletcher
