Australian Bushfires
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your letter dated 9 April 2020 to the Prime Minister, the Hon Scott Morrison MP, regarding petition number EN1247 which calls on the Commonwealth Government to establish a Royal Commission into the 2019-20 Australian bushfires. The Prime Minister has asked me to respond on his behalf and I apologise for the delay in responding.

I am pleased to advise that the Royal Commission into National Natural Disaster Arrangements was established on 20 February 2020. The Royal Commission focuses on three key areas of inquiry. What should be done to improve natural disaster management coordination across all levels of government, what should be done to improve Australia's resilience and adaptation to changing climatic conditions, and the legal framework for the Commonwealth's involvement in responding to national emergencies.

The latter line of inquiry includes whether there should be a new power for the Commonwealth Government to declare a national state of emergency to trigger direct Commonwealth Government responses to national disasters, including the direct deployment of the Australian Defence Force.

The Royal Commission will also examine ways in which Australia could achieve greater national coordination and consistency with respect to preparedness and resilience responsibilities for matters such as land management, species conservation and land-use planning.

The overwhelming majority of actions to protect Australians from bushfires are undertaken at State level. Following consultation with State Premiers and Territory Chief Ministers, the Prime Minister asked State Premiers to make this a truly national and joint inquiry by issuing commissions in complementary terms under respective State Royal Commissions laws.

The Royal Commission is led by former Chief of the Defence Force, Air Chief Marshal Mark Binskin AC (Retd), who is joined by the Honourable Dr Annabelle Bennett AC SC, a former Federal Court judge, and by Professor Andrew Macintosh, a specialist in climate risk and impact management.

The Royal Commission is an independent inquiry and responsible for how it conducts its inquiry. Information about the Royal Commission is available on its website at www.naturaldisaster.royalcommission.gov.au.

The Government is continuing the work needed to help rebuild communities and livelihoods. The National Bushfire Recovery Agency has an initial $2 billion commitment for bushfire recovery efforts. This is in addition to other support we are providing through the Disaster Recovery Funding Arrangements and the Disaster Recovery Payments and Allowances. We are here to support recovery for the long-term.
I have copied this letter to the Minister for Agriculture, Drought and Emergency Management, the Hon David Littleproud MP.
Thank you for bringing this petition to the attention of the Prime Minister.
from the Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister and Cabinet, Mr Morton
Climate Change
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 16 April 2020 regarding Petition EN1248. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

Australia has a responsibility to play our part in reducing greenhouse gas emissions, while also making sure we have affordable electricity and a strong economy. While it is not widely reported, Australia's emissions are coming down. In fact:
Australia's emissions are lower now than when the Coalition came to Government in 2013.

Australia's emissions are more than 12 per cent lower than 2005 levels (the year from which our 2030 Paris target is measured). This compares to a two per cent reduction for Canada and a four per cent increase for New Zealand, over the same period.

Looking forward, Australia's 2030 target is for a 26-28 per cent reduction on 2005 levels, On a per person basis, our target is more ambitious than the European Union, Germany, Canada, New Zealand or Japan have committed to over the same period.

The $3.5 billion Climate Solutions Package maps out how we will meet our 2030 target down to the last tonne. The latest official projections show that we are on track to meet and beat our 2030 target by 16 million tonnes. Under United Nations rules, countries including Australia are able to use emissions budgets to account for their Paris Agreement targets. For example, an emission budget approach is central to how the European Union acquits its targets.

But there is much more to do and our role in the global response to climate change can go well beyond reducing our own emissions. The pathway to meaningful impacts on global emissions is through development and deployment of new technologies. The answer is not a new tax or more bureaucracy but practical change driven by science and technology. This is where Australia can have the biggest impact on reducing global emissions.

The Liberal National Government has already invested $10.4 billion into more than 670 clean energy projects with a total value of $35 billion. These projects include the largest pumped hydro scheme in the southern hemisphere, Snowy 2.0, hydrogen demonstration projects and
bio fuels. Our investments are supporting new jobs, reducing power prices and improving the reliability of our electricity grid while lowering emissions.

The key challenge to ensuring power prices continue to come down and continued strong growth in renewable energy is to drive down the cost of storage and backup. That's why the Government has established a $1 billion Grid Reliability Fund to support investment in the new generation, energy storage and transmission needed to keep bringing power prices down and make sure the lights stay on. All of this is focused on achieving our emissions obligations while maintaining a strong economy.

The Government will soon be releasing a Technology Investment Roadmap for public consultation. Consultation on the Roadmap will inform the development of the first annual Clean Technology Statement, which will identify technology priorities and ensure the Government's investment portfolio can be refined and updated.

The Government has also committed to develop a Long-Term Emissions Reduction Strategy ahead of C0P26. Australia's long-term strategy will be framed around technology pathways for key sectors, recognising that technology presents opportunities for Australian businesses to boost productivity, create jobs and remain globally competitive in a world where markets increasingly value low emissions. This will be particularly important as Australia and the world recovers from the COVID-19 pandemic.

The long-term strategy will also draw from and integrate relevant work underway across government, including the Technology Investment Roadmap, National Hydrogen Strategy, Electric Vehicle Strategy and the work of the Carbon Expert Panel chaired by Mr Grant King.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Energy and Emissions Reduction, Mr Taylor
Closing the Gap
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your letter dated 9 April 2020 to the Prime Minister, the Hon Scott Morrison MP, concerning the petition number EN1308. I note the petition calls for the House of Representatives to implement the recommendations of the Final Report of the Referendum Council delivered on 30 June 2017. The Prime Minister has asked me to respond on his behalf. I sincerely apologise for the delay in responding to you.

The Referendum Council's Final Report recommended a single constitutional change to enshrine an Indigenous representative body to advise Parliament on legislation relating to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians. However, the Referendum Council did not provide the detail of a voice, so the 2018 Joint Select Committee into Constitutional Recognition relating to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples was tasked with considering how to progress this issue. In his February 2020 Closing the Gap address to Parliament, the Prime Minister stated the Government's acceptance of all four of the Joint Select Committee's recommendations.

The Australian Government is committed to enabling Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians to achieve better health, education and safety outcomes so this generation, and the next, can have the same expectations and opportunities as any other Australian. Part of this is ensuring Indigenous voices are heard at all levels of government. We need to hear from Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians on the matters and policies that affect them. There are many views on how to achieve this, and we need to ensure we hear them.

That is why the Government is undertaking a co-design process to develop options for a voice for Indigenous Australians. This is consistent with the 2018 Joint Select Committee's recommendation that a process of co-design be initiated across Australia for an Indigenous voice. The Minister for Indigenous Australians, the Hon Ken Wyatt AM MP, is leading this work.

The Government is also committed to constitutional recognition of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians. It will be important to develop a shared approach and vision, with a real consensus, that will deliver on the aspirations of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians and be supported by all Australians. This approach is also supported by the 2018 Joint Select Committee, which recommended considering constitutional recognition after the process of co-design is complete.

The Government acknowledges there are many views on how an Indigenous voice should be designed. We need to work together to gain agreement on something that will work. I thank these petitioners for bringing forward their views to the Prime Minister, so we can all work together to achieve change on this important issue. I trust this information will be of assistance in responding to the petitioners.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister and Cabinet, Mr Morton
Transport Industry
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 9 April 2020, originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petition EN1340 - Luxury car tax. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response. I apologise for the delay in responding to you.

The Luxury Car Tax (LCT) threshold is now in (2020-21) $77,565 for fuel-efficient vehicles and $68,740 for other vehicles. The LCT (at a rate of 33 per cent) only applies to the part of the price above the relevant threshold. Further information on the threshold for LCT can be found at www.ato.gov.au against QC38161.

In the regulation impact statement accompanying the legislation giving effect to the change, the then Australian Government noted that the policy objective was to maintain existing Government policy with respect to the taxation of luxury cars, relative to non-luxury cars.

In response to your question about the removal of LCT, from battery only electric vehicles. The Government is not currently considering removing the LCT, which has existed in one form or another for many years. The Government uses the revenue from the LCT to fund essential services that all Australians benefit from such as health, education, defence and security.

By way of background, on 1 July 2008, the luxury car tax was raised from 25 per cent to 33 per cent as part of a package to enhance fairness in the tax system, announced in the 2008-09 Budget. The then Government, when introducing the reform into Parliament, noted that Australians who could afford luxury vehicles had the capacity to contribute to revenue at a higher rate than other car buyers.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Housing and Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
Transport Industry
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 8 April 2020, originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petition EN1342 - Luxury car tax on zero emission cars. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response. I apologise for the delay in responding to you.

The Luxury Car Tax (LCT) was put in place in 2000 to ensure that the price of luxury cars did not fall substantially, relative to the price of standard vehicles, with the abolition of the wholesale sales taxes.

As the petitioners may be aware, the LCT is levied across all vehicles over respective thresholds. In 2020-21, fuel efficient vehicles (defined as those with a fuel consumption of 7 litres/100 km or less), including electric vehicles, have a threshold of $77,565 before the tax is applied. This is $8,825 higher than the other vehicle threshold of $68,740. At the LCT rate of 33 per cent, this translates to a tax saving of over $2,900 on fuel efficient vehicles, including electric vehicles, priced over $77,565 compared to other vehicles subject to the LCT.

The Australian Government is not currently considering removing the LCT, which has existed in one form or another for many years. The Government uses the revenue from the LCT to fund essential services that all Australians benefit from such as health, education, defence and security.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Housing and Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
Parliamentarians
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your letter dated 9 April 2020 to the Prime Minister, the Hon Scott Morrison MP, regarding a petition relating to the Newstart Allowance and the introduction of drug and alcohol testing for Members of the Parliament (Petition number EN1348 refers). The Prime Minister has asked me to reply on his behalf.

The Social Services Legislation Amendment (Drug Testing Trial) Bill 2019, which is currently before the Senate, establishes a drug testing trial for new recipients of the former Newstart Allowance (now known as the JobSeeker Allowance) or the Youth Allowance (Other). The two-year drug testing trial will be held in three locations across Australia: Canterbury-Bankstown (NSW), Logan (Queensland) and Mandurah (Western Australia). Those who claim the allowances in these locations may be selected for random drug testing.

The trial is not about punishing people. Recipients of the allowances will not lose their funding for failing a drug test. The trial is about assisting people to pursue treatment options to address their drug abuse issues.

Those who test positive will have their income support payments quarantined through Income Management. This does not change the amount of money they receive, but can make it easier for those affected by drug use to ensure their payments are spent on essential things such as rent, childcare and food.

Recipients of the allowances who test positive to a second test will be referred to a medical professional who will assess their circumstances and identify treatment options. As part of the trial, the Government will deliver a $10 million Treatment Fund to boost drug treatment capacity in trial sites and help ensure recipients can access the support they need.
Through the trial, the Government will be able to assess the effectiveness of this approach in helping get people with drug abuse issues to get off welfare and into a job.

The Prime Minister has indicated that he has no objection to the introduction of a similar drug testing trial for parliamentarians. However, the decision to implement drug testing for parliamentarians would be a decision for each chamber of the Parliament to consider.
Thank you for bringing this issue to the Prime Minister's attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister and Cabinet, Mr Morton
National Emblem
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your letter dated 9 April 2020 , to the Prime Minister, the Hon Scott Morrison MP, enclosing petition EN1355, which requests that the Government change the national bird of Australia. The Prime Minister has asked me to respond on his behalf as I am the Minister responsible for national symbols policy.

While the emu features in the Commonwealth Coat of Arms, there has been no proclamation or formal recognition of a national bird. The Government has no plans to recognise a national bird or change the Commonwealth Coat of Arms.

Various Australian state and territory governments have formally recognised a bird emblem. It is interesting to note that the Northern Territory has already recognised the wedge-tailed eagle, as it features in the Northern Territory Coat of Arms.
Further information about the Northern Territory symbols is available on the Northern Government website at https://nt.gov.au/about-government/official-symbols-and-emblems.
Thank you for bringing this petition to the Government's attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister and Cabinet, Mr Morton
Skilled Regional Visas
Dear Mr Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 13 May 2020 concerning Petition EN1378 regarding processing timeframes for Skilled Regional (subclass 887) visas.
The Acting Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, the Hon Alan Tudge MP, has asked that I respond on his behalf.
The Department of Home Affairs acknowledges the time and resources applicants invest into their Skilled Regional visa applications.

The current average processing timeframe for 75 per cent of subclass 887 visas is 21 months, with 90 per cent processed in 22 months. The Department has directed additional resources towards the processing of this caseload, and is currently assessing subclass 887 visa applications that were submitted before December 2019.

Processing timeframes may be affected by a number of issues, including current application pipelines, completeness and quality of applications, and the need for integrity checking to verify claims. The majority of applications for this subclass require further requests for information before a decision can be made.

I appreciate that current holders of the Skilled Regional (Provisional) (subclass 489) visa are concerned about delays in having their permanent visas finalised, and that this has led to uncertainty about their status. A subclass 489 visa holder awaiting the outcome of their permanent visa application can continue to live, work and study in a specified region of Australia. This visa is valid for four years and allows travel to and from Australia noting that in the current environment, travel restrictions may apply. Further information on travel restrictions is available on the Department's at: https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au.

For migration purposes, most locations of Australia outside major cities are classed as designated regional areas. This ensures that migrants are provided with a range of opportunities to live and work in Australia's smaller cities and regions. Further information on eligible regional areas is available on the Department's website at: https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/visas/working-in-australia/regional-migration/eligible-regional-areas.

The Australian Government works closely with state, territory and local governments, and local communities to attract migrants to regional areas. Skilled migrants settling in regional Australia have a diverse range of available occupations to match their experience, skills and qualifications. This assists migrants to establish themselves in the Australian labour market and settle into life in Australia.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN1378 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Customs, Community Safety and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Wood
Transport Industry
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 13 May 2020 originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petition EN1381 - incentives to purchase electric vehicles. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response. I apologise for the delay in responding to you.

As part of the $3.5 billion Climate Solutions Package, the Australian Government is developing a National Electric Vehicle Strategy. The Strategy will address the barriers to uptake so that Australians who choose to adopt new technologies are able to do so. For more information, refer to: www.publications.industry.gov.au/publications/climate-change/climate-change/government/national-vehicle-strategy.html.

This Strategy includes examining public and private charging infrastructure, exploring the integration of electric vehicle charging with the electricity system, and industry opportunities. The Strategy will build on existing Government support including:
$21 million of funding for charging infrastructure through the Australian Renewable Energy Agency to roll out ultra-fast charging sites through two networks along Australia's national highways;
up to $1.1 billion in finance available through the Clean Energy Finance Corporation to assist uptake of low and zero emissions vehicles finance ; and
$25 million for the Future Battery Industries Cooperative Research Centre.

As the petitioners may be aware, the Luxury Car Tax (LCT) is levied across all vehicles over respective thresholds. In 2020-21, fuel efficient vehicles (defined as those with a fuel consumption of 7 litres/100 km or less), including electric vehicles, have a threshold of $77,565 before the tax is applied. This is $8,825 higher than the other vehicle threshold of $68,740. At the LCT rate of 33 per cent, this translates to a tax saving of over $2,900 on fuel efficient vehicles, including electric vehicles, priced over $77,565 compared to other vehicles subject to the LCT.
I trust information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Housing and Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
Domestic and Family Violence
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your email dated 15 June 2020 to the Attorney General the Hon Christian Porter MP, concerning petition EN1427. As the matter raised falls within my portfolio responsibility, your email has been forwarded to me for reply.
In Australia, state and territory governments are responsible for the statutory care and protection of children and young people experiencing, or at risk of, abuse or neglect.
However, the number of children suffering abuse and neglect is of concern to all governments.

The Australian Government is committed to keeping women and their children safe from violence. The Government strongly believes that domestic and family violence and sexual assault in our community are unacceptable and everyone has the right to live free from harm and without fear of violence or abuse.

This is why we are working with state and territory governments, non-government organisations and across the community to take action through the National Plan to Reduce Violence against Women and their Children 2010-2022 (the National Plan).

The National Plan is built on the understanding that gender inequality is one of the main causes of family and domestic violence. For this reason, there is a strong focus on changing community attitudes around both gender equality and violence against women and their children, in order to effect long-term change and stop violence before it occurs.

This is why the record $340 million Fourth Action Plan of the National Plan has made significant investments in primary prevention. These policies and programs will help lay the foundations for generational change; a vital step towards reducing domestic and family violence across Australia.
For more information on the Fourth Action Plan, I encourage you to visit plan4womenssafety.dss.gov.au.

The Government also works in partnership with state and territory governments and the community sector under the National Framework for Protecting Australia's Children 2009-2020 (the National Framework), which aims to ensure Australia's children and young people are safe and well.

The National Framework focuses on addressing complex problems which require joined up, concentrated effort from the federal and state and territory governments, and the non-government sector. Protecting children is everyone's business and the National Framework emphasises the role of parents, families, communities and governments in ensuring the safety and wellbeing of Australia's children.
The Fourth Action Plan of the National Framework contains four priority areas, one of which is to improve prevention and early intervention responses through joint service planning and investment.
Thank you again for raising this matter with me.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Families and Social Services, Senator Ruston
COVID-19
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 15 June 2020, originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petition EN1431, relating to support for the hospitality industry. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response. Please accept my sincere apologies for being slow to respond. I have received a large number of emails and requests for information and have not been able to respond as quickly as I would like.

In response to the petition, I can advise that the Australian Government has acted decisively to help households and businesses and address the significant economic consequences of the Coronavirus. A total of $305 billion is being injected into the economy in order to keep Australians in work and businesses in business. The Government's economic support package includes a number of measures to support Australian businesses to retain employees and manage cash flow challenges during the Coronavirus.
Below is a summary of the Government assistance that is available for hospitality businesses, particularly small businesses, in Brisbane.
JOBKEEPER PAYMENT
On 30 March 2020, the Government introduced a wage subsidy program, which was originally due to run until 27 September 2020, to support employees and businesses.
Under the JobKeeper Payment, up until 27 September 2020, eligible businesses and not-for-profits receive
$1,500 per fortnight before tax per eligible employee to cover the cost of wages. This means more employees can retain their job and continue to earn an income.
On 21 July 2020, the Government announced that the JobKeeper Payment will be extended by six months,
until 28 March 2021. Businesses wishing to claim JobKeeper during the extension period will be required to reassess their turnover and the payment will also change to a two tiered payment.
The Australian Taxation Office (ATO) is administering the JobKeeper Payment. Further information for the petitioner is available on the ATO website: www.ato.gov.au/General/JobKeeper-Payment/.
BOOSTING CASH FLOW FOR EMPLOYERS

The Government is providing tax-free cash flow boosts of between $20,000 and $100,000 to eligible small and medium businesses and not-for-profit organisations (NFPs), so they can keep operating, pay their rent, electricity and other bills, and retain staff.

Eligible employers receive these boosts as credits upon lodging their activity statements for the March to September 2020 periods. Where this places an employer in a refund position, the ATO will generally deliver the refund within 14 days.

Eligible employers who withhold tax to the ATO on their employees' salary and wages will receive an initial cash flow boost equal to 100 per cent of the amount withheld, up to a maximum payment of $50,000. Eligible employers receive a minimum initial cash flow boost of $10,000, even if they are not required to withhold tax.
The initial cash flow boost is credited upon lodgement of activity statements for the March to June 2020 periods. Initial cash flow boosts have been credited since 19 April 2020.

Employers who receive initial cash flow boosts will also receive additional cash flow boosts upon lodging their activity statements for the June to September 2020 periods. These additional cash flow boosts will be equal to the total amount of initial cash flow boosts received. This means that eligible businesses that employ people will receive at least $20,000 up to $100,000 in total cash flow boosts.
For further information, the petitioner can visit the ATO website:
www.ato.gov.au/uploadedFiles/Content/SPR/downloads/CFB-eligibility-companion-guide.pdf.
TEMPORARY RELIEF FOR FINANCIALLY DISTRESSED BUSINESSES

The economic impacts of the Coronavirus and health measures to prevent its spread are seeing many otherwise profitable and viable businesses temporarily face financial distress. It is important that these businesses have a safety net to make sure that when the crisis has passed they can resume normal operations.

To make sure that businesses have confidence to continue to trade through the Coronavirus health crisis with the aim of returning to viability when the crisis has passed, directors have been temporarily relieved of their duty to prevent insolvent trading with respect to any debts incurred in the ordinary course of the company's business. This relieves the director of personal liability that would otherwise be associated with the insolvent trading. It will apply until 31 December 2020.

The Government has also temporarily increased the cm-rent minimum threshold for creditors issuing a statutory demand on a company under the Corporations Act 2001 from $2,000 to $20,000 and temporarily extended the timeframe for a company to respond to a statutory demand from 21 days to six months.

The Government also has a temporary power to provide targeted relief to businesses from provisions of the Corporations Act 2001, where it is appropriate to do so to facilitate the continuation of business or mitigate the economic impact of the Coronavirus health crisis.
BOOSTING THE INSTANT ASSET WRITE-OFF

The Government has increased the instant asset write-off threshold from $30,000 to $150,000 and expanded access to include businesses with aggregated annual turnover of less than $500 million (up from $50 million), until 31 December 2020.
BACKING BUSINESS INVESTMENT
The Government has introducing a time-limited 15 month investment incentive by accelerating depreciation deductions (through to 30 June 2021).

Businesses with a turnover of less than $500 million will be able to deduct 50 per cent of the cost of an eligible asset on installation, with existing depreciation rules applying to the balance of the asset's cost.
IMMEDIATE CASH FLOW NEEDS FOR SMEs
The Coronavirus SME Guarantee Scheme will enhance access to working capital for small and medium enterprises (SMEs) to help them through the impact of Coronavirus.

Under the Scheme, the Government will provide a guarantee of 50 per cent to SME lenders to support up to $40 billion worth of new loans. This will enhance lenders' willingness and ability to provide credit, which will result in SMEs being able to access additional funding to help support them through the upcoming months.
The initial phase of the Scheme is available for new loans made by participating lenders until

30 September 2020. As the economy continues to open up, the Government will extend and enhance the Scheme to help businesses recover. The second phase will start on 1 October 2020 and will be available for new loans made until 30 June 2021.
For more information about the Scheme, the petitioner can refer to: www.treasury.gov.au/coronavinis/sme-guarantee-scheme.
QUICK AND EFFICIENT ACCESS TO CREDIT FOR SMALL BUSINESS

The Government has cut red tape by providing a temporary exemption from responsible lending obligations for lenders providing credit to existing small business customers. Responsible lending obligations do not currently apply to lending which is predominantly for a business purpose, but it can take time and effort for lenders to be satisfied that the money borrowed meets this test. By providing a temporary exemption from responsible lending obligations, this reform will help small businesses get access to credit quickly and efficiently.
FLOW OF CREDIT

The Government, the Reserve Bank of Australia and the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority have taken coordinated action to ensure the flow of credit in the Australian economy. Timely access to credit is vital for businesses to manage the impacts of the Coronavirus.
Further information is available at: www.treasury.gov.au/coronavirusibusinesses. I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Housing and Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
Taxation
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 15 June 2020 concerning petition EN1438 regarding representation for taxpayers on Special Category (SCV) (subclass 444) visas which was presented in the House of Representatives on the same date. The Minister for Home Affairs, the Hon Peter Dutton MP, has asked that I respond on his behalf.

I note the concerns raised by petitioners about the status of New Zealand (NZ) citizens in Australia. Under the 1973 Trans-Tasman Travel Arrangement, NZ citizens who hold NZ passports and present no health or character concerns can visit, live and work in Australia indefinitely and without restrictions — a benefit Australia has not conferred on any other nation.
Since 1 September 1994, all non-citizens in Australia have been required to hold a valid visa. As a result, the SCV, a temporary visa, was introduced specifically for NZ citizens.

Prior to February 2001, NZ citizens in Australia on a SCV could access social security and obtain Australian citizenship without first becoming permanent residents. In February 2001, Australia entered into a new bilateral social security arrangement with NZ and amended citizenship laws for NZ citizens. Under these changes, all NZ citizens who arrived in Australia after 26 February 2001, and who want to access certain social security payments, obtain Australian citizenship or sponsor family members for permanent residence may only do so after applying for, and being granted, permanent residence.

These changes were intended to provide a fair and mutually beneficial approach to the costs of supporting people in need, while preserving the common labour market and free movement of people available through the Trans-Tasman Travel Arrangement. These changes placed NZ citizens taking up residence in Australia on the same basis as other migrants.

You may be aware that in acknowledgement of the special bilateral relationship between Australia and NZ, on 1 July 2017, a dedicated and streamlined pathway to Australian permanent residence commenced for NZ citizens who arrived in Australia on or before 19 February 2016, have been living in Australia for at least five years, and have shown a commitment and contribution to Australia. This pathway is through the NZ stream of the Skilled Independent (subclass 189) visa. More information is available on the Department of Home Affairs' website at: https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/visas/getting-a-visa/visa-listing/skilled-independent¬189/new-zealand.

As the Skilled Independent visa is a permanent visa, holders of this visa are eligible to apply for Australian citizenship by conferral, provided they meet the general eligibility requirements, including the general residence requirement. This requires applicants to have lived in Australia on a valid visa for the past four years, including the last 12 months as a permanent resident.

Information to assist NZ citizens to consider possible pathways to Australian permanent residence and Australian citizenship is available on the Department's website at: https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/entering-and-leaving-australia/new¬zealand-citizens/pathway-to-permanent-resident-and-citizenship.
General information on the requirements for citizenship by conferral can also be found on the Department's website at: https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/citizenship/ become-a-citizen.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN1438 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Customs, Community Safety and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Wood
Migration
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 15 June 2020 concerning Petition EN1448 regarding processing timeframes for Skilled Regional (subclass 887) visas.
The Acting Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, the Hon Alan Tudge MP, has asked that I respond on his behalf.
The Department of Home Affairs acknowledges the time and resources applicants invest into their Skilled Regional visa applications.

The current average processing timeframe for 75 per cent of subclass 887 visas is 21 months, with 90 per cent processed in 22 months. The Department is currently assessing subclass 887 visa applications that were submitted before December 2019.
Processing timeframes may be affected by a number of issues, including current application pipelines, completeness and quality of applications, and the need for integrity checking to verify claims.

I appreciate that current holders of the Skilled Regional (Provisional) (subclass 489) visa are concerned about delays in having their permanent subclass 887 visas finalised, and that this has led to uncertainty about their status. A subclass 489 visa holder, awaiting the outcome of their permanent subclass 887 visa application, can continue to live, work and study in a specified region of Australia. The subclass 489 visa is valid for four years and allows travel to and from Australia, noting that travel restrictions may apply. Further information on travel restrictions is available on the Department's website at: https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au.

For migration purposes, locations outside major cities in Australia are classified as designated regional areas. This ensures that migrants are provided with a range of opportunities to live and work in Australia's smaller cities and regions. Further information on eligible regional areas is available on the Department's website at:
https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/visas/working-in-australia/regional-migration/eligible¬regional-areas.

The Australian Government works closely with state, territory and local governments, and local communities to attract migrants to regional areas. Skilled migrants settling in regional Australia have a diverse range of available occupations to match their experience, skills and qualifications. This assists migrants to establish themselves in the Australian labour market and settle into life in Australia.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN1448 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Customs, Community Safety and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Wood
Banking and Financial Services
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence, originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petition EN1453 relating to credit card interest rates. Your correspondence has been referred to me as I have responsibility for this matter.

It is important to note that interest rates on individual products are commercial decisions for lenders. The Government does not intervene in these decisions. However, despite the official cash rate having been cut to a record low, credit card interest rates remain high and we understand this is understandably a source of frustration for people who are trying to pay off credit card balances.

The Government has taken action in recent years to implement reforms to improve consumer outcomes and enhancing competition in the credit card market, therefore allowing consumers to shop around for a product which best suits their needs. Reforms introduced in 2018 include:
a requirement that credit card affordability assessments be based on a consumer's ability to repay the credit limit within a three year period;
banning unsolicited offers of credit limit increases;
simplifying how credit card interest is calculated; and
requiring credit card providers to have online options to cancel cards or to reduce credit limits.

These measures complement other Government actions to improve competition and consumer outcomes in the credit card market, including reforms to ban excessive credit card surcharges and provide the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) strong powers to enforce the ban.
I trust this information will be of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Superannuation, Financial Services and Financial Technology, Senator Hume
Migration

COVID-19
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 15 June 2020 concerning Petition EN1460 and employment conditions for Temporary Work (Skilled) (subclass 457) visa holders affected by the COVID-19 pandemic. The Acting Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, the Hon Alan Tudge MP, has asked I respond on his behalf.

The Australian Government has made a number of changes to temporary visa holder arrangements during the COVID-19 period in order to protect the health of our community, safeguard job opportunities for Australians, support critical industries, and assist with the rapid recovery post the virus. For example:
temporary skilled visa holders who have been stood down, but not laid off, will maintain their visa validity and businesses will have the opportunity to extend their visa as per normal arrangements;
businesses will be able to reduce the hours of temporary skilled visa holders without the person being in breach of their visa condition; and

temporary skilled visa holders who are re-employed in Australia after the COVID-19 pandemic will be able to count their time already spent in Australia towards their permanent residence skilled work experience requirements.

More broadly, the Government has allocated $7 million in funding to the Australian Red Cross (ARC) to provide emergency relief to temporary visa holders, with temporary visa holders also able to access relief services from other community organisations, receiving a total of $200 million new funding. More information is available on the ARC's website at: https://www.redcross.org.au/news-and-media/ news/help-for-migrants-in-transition.

Temporary visa holders are extremely valuable to the Australian economy and way of life. However, the reality is that many Australians will find themselves out of work due to the dual health and economic challenges currently being faced, and these Australians and permanent residents must be the Government's first priority.

There has always been an expectation that temporary visa holders are able to support themselves while in Australia. That expectation remains, noting that on 4 April 2020, the Government encouraged temporary visa holders who are no longer able to support themselves to return home where it is possible to do so. While international travel options have become more limited, departure is still possible for many.

The Government will continue, over the coming weeks and months, to monitor the impact of the broad range of public health, economic and support measures taken to protect the Australian community, and respond as necessary to protect Australians' health and to support economic recovery.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN1460 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Customs, Community Safety and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Wood
Intellectual Property
Dear Chair

Thank you for your letter dated 15 June 2020 regarding petition EN1468, which requests the repeal of section 115A of the Copyright Act 1968 (the Copyright Act), with the intention that this would allow for faster distribution of content to Australia once it has aired in the United States of America (US).

I note the petitioner's concern that the disabling of access to copyright infringing online locations has led to delays in the time between when the latest episodes of television series are broadcast in the US to when those episodes become available in Australia.

The aim of the Copyright Act is to enable creators of content such as movies, music and books to be appropriately rewarded for their creative endeavours. Under the Copyright Act, copyright owners have the right to control how, and when, their content is accessed via the internet.

Copyright material made available on the internet which does not have the permission of the copyright owner, or distributor, is likely to be an infringement of copyright, generally known as piracy. The availability of copyright infringing material will often negatively affect the ability for the copyright owner to gain income from their content. People operating piracy websites that host copyright infringing material are able to profit at the creator's expense.

The Morrison Government is committed to addressing online copyright infringement and introduced section 115A into the Copyright Act in 2015 to provide an efficient mechanism to disable access to infringing online locations (such as piracy websites) outside Australia. Section 115A contains a number of safeguards to address concerns that the power could be used to censor access to content or websites used for legitimate purposes, or to impact on other important public and private interests. The section is only intended to capture websites operated overseas where it is established by the Court that the primary purpose of the website is to infringe, or facilitate the infringement of, copyright material.

Only copyright owners can apply for a Court order for the blocking foreign websites that infringe their copyright, or facilitate infringement. The power also provides a number of factors that the Court may consider to help balance competing public and private interests in determining whether to grant an injunction or not. These include whether disabling access to the website is a proportionate response in the circumstances, and whether it is in the overall public interest.

Websites that facilitate large scale infringement of copyright negatively affect Australia's creators, creative industries and the people they employ. The repeal of section 115A of the Copyright Act would not alter the illegal nature of these infringing online locations, it would only reduce the ability for copyright owners to protect their content, and thus their ability to invest in the production of future content.

The Government response to the Australian Competition & Consumer Commission's Digital Platforms Inquiry report acknowledged that Australia's copyright system is critically important to our economy and our creative industries. The Government has committed to reviewing the online enforcement regime for late 2020, including the effectiveness of section 115A of the Copyright Act. The Government will be consulting further and seeking more data from copyright stakeholders, digital platforms and consumer groups.

Finally, copyright owners can arrange for the distribution of their content in different international territories as they consider appropriate, to support all those involved in the creative process, as well as to earn a commercial return on their works.

The territorial nature of copyright protection means that Australian distributors of US copyright material must comply with their contractual obligations in distributing that content to the Australian market, including any limitations on time of release.

However, the Government is also mindful of the needs of consumers to access the content they desire. The Government continues to encourage copyright owners to provide fairly priced and high quality access to TV shows and movies, in a timely fashion where these are from foreign territories including the US.
Thank you for bringing the petitioner's concerns to my attention. I hope the information in this letter is of some help.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Cyber Safety and the Arts, Mr Fletcher
COVID-19
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your letter concerning petition number EN1477 regarding sunset clauses on the emergency powers enacted by the Australian Government in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. I apologise for the delay in responding.

The Governor-General has declared that a human biosecurity emergency exists concerning the listed human disease 'human coronavirus with pandemic potential' under Chapter 8 of the Biosecurity Act 2015 (Act). The Governor-General's declaration and the other emergency requirements that I have made under the Act have been necessary and appropriate to prevent or control the entry, emergence, establishment and spread of COVID-19 in Australia.

The powers in Chapter 8 of the Act are designed to apply for a limited time, and only during a declared human biosecurity emergency period. The human biosecurity emergency can only last as long as necessary and must be reconsidered by the Governor-General every three months.

Any determination of emergency requirements made under Chapter 8 following such a declaration is subject to a number of legal tests, including that the period during which the requirement is to apply is only as long as is necessary. The Act empowers me to revoke a determination made under Chapter 8 earlier than the cessation of the human biosecurity emergency period if I consider it is no longer necessary for it to remain in effect and these measures can only remain in effect for the period of the emergency.

State and territory governments have also responded to the pandemic based on the medical advice from their respective Chief Health Officers and a range of emergency measures have been enacted under relevant state and territory public health legislation to manage COVID-19.

The Government has taken a strong and decisive approach in responding to COVID-19, based on the medical advice provided by the Commonwealth Chief Medical Officer and the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee.

We have acted and continue to act with appropriate urgency and immediacy to protect the human health and life of Australians during the COVID-19 pandemic. We are fully committed to keeping Australians as safe and well as possible during this pandemic.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health, Mr Hunt
World Health Organization
Dear Mr O'Dowd
I refer to your letter concerning petition number EN1500, requesting the Australian Government to freeze funding for the World Health Organization (WHO). I regret the delay in responding.

As the leading authority for health within the United Nations (UN), the WHO is the cornerstone of an effective rules-based international order for health, and plays a central role in preventing, detecting and coordinating a global response to health emergencies.

The Government's recent audit of its multilateral engagement found that Australia's interests are not served by stepping away and leaving others to shape decisions and outcomes in the international order. Australia's interests are better served by wOrking to ensure multilateral institutions are fit for purpose to address current challenges, accountable to member states, free from undue influence and politicisation, and focused appropriately on our Indo-Pacific region.

The COVID-19 pandemic is an unprecedented global crisis that has brought out the shortcomings and strengths in the current global health architecture. This is why Australia has called for, and is committed to pursuing, an impartial, independent and comprehensive review into the pandemic to help the international community learn the lessons necessary to protect global health. The global response to COVID-19 has also demonstrated a level of global collaboration, including through the WHO, demonstrating a key strength of the system. The record number of co-sponsors (145) of the World Health Assembly (WHA) resolution on the COVID-19 response sends a strong signal of international cooperation and solidarity in the face of this unprecedented pandemic.

The WHA resolution on COVID-19 seeks collaboration across the UN system to identify the zoonotic source of the virus and its introduction to the human population and calls for an independent and comprehensive evaluation of the global response. The evaluation will examine the effectiveness of the mechanisms at the international community's disposal as well as the actions of the WHO, and will make recommendations to improve global pandemic prevention, preparedness, and response.

As the source of the virus has not yet been definitively identified, the WHA resolution provides a mandate for continued work to identify this including through scientific and collaborative missions to China. The Government acknowledges the importance of international efforts to determine the source of the virus, so that we can learn important lessons and inform the development of targeted interventions and guidance to help us prevent another devastating event like COVID-19. We also recognise that fundamental changes are needed at the global level to prevent another pandemic of zoonotic origins, which is why we have made a concerted global effort to reduce high-risk human-wildlife interactions, such as those occurring at wildlife wet markets.
The WHO is a longstanding partner of the Government, given its normative lead role and technical expertise on global health issues, including in the Indo-Pacific region.
The Prime Minister, the Hon Scott Morrison MP has highlighted the important work the WHO undertakes in supporting emergency preparedness and response in the Indo-Pacific region.
The WHO is crucial to coordinating the global response to the pandemic, and the Government does not plan to reduce or suspend funding to this important global health organisation.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health, Mr Hunt
Education
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your email of 15 June 2020 regarding Petition EN1501. In response to the issues raised in the petition I can provide the following advice.

The Foundation to Year 10 Australian Curriculum, endorsed by all Education Ministers in 2015, sets the expectations for what all students should be taught regardless of where they live or their background. Ministers agreed at the December 2019 Education Council meeting to fast track a review of the Australian Curriculum and the Education Council has now agreed to the Terms of Reference for the review. There will be extensive consultation, including with professional and key stakeholder groups.

While the Australian Government takes a leadership role in matters of national education policy, the delivery of school education is a matter for state and territory government and non-government education authorities. The petitioner may wish to contact their state or territory education minister to discuss their concerns. Contact details are attached.
Thank you for raising this matter with me.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Education, Mr Tehan

World Health Organization
Dear Chair
I refer to your letter of 15 June 2020 concerning petition number EN1503, asking the House to completely withdraw Australian funding of the World Health Organization (WHO).

It is in everyone's interest to have the best possible global health architecture equipped to respond to future health crises. As the leading authority for health within the United Nations (UN), the WHO is the cornerstone of an effective rules-based international order for health, and plays a central role in preventing, detecting and coordinating a global response to health emergencies. Australia sees the WHO as an important partner to coordinate the global response to COVID-19.

The Government's recent audit of its multilateral engagement found that Australia's interests are served not by stepping away and leaving others to shape decisions and outcomes in the international order, but by working to ensure multilateral institutions are fit for purpose to address current challenges, accountable to member states, free from undue influence and politicisation, and focused appropriately on our Indo-Pacific region.

The COVID-19 pandemic is an unprecedented global crisis that has brought out the shortcomings and strengths in the current global health architecture. This is why Australia has called for, and is committed to pursuing, an impartial, independent and comprehensive evaluation into the pandemic to help the international community learn the lessons necessary to protect global health. The global response to COVID-19 has also demonstrated a level of global collaboration, including through the WHO, demonstrating a key strength of the system. The record number of co-sponsors (145) of the World Health Assembly (WHA) on the COVID-19 Response sends a strong signal of international cooperation and solidarity in the face of this unprecedented pandemic.

The WHA resolution on COVID-19 seeks collaboration across the UN system to identify the zoonotic source of the virus and its introduction to the human population and calls for an independent and comprehensive evaluation of the global response.

The evaluation will examine the effectiveness of the mechanisms at the international community's disposal as well as the actions of the WHO and will make recommendations to improve global pandemic prevention, preparedness, and response.

As a current member of the WHO Executive Board, Australia has taken a strong and principled position on governance and technical policy matters. Australia has utilised this position to encourage reform where necessary, and to support regional health priorities, particularly those of our neighbours in the Pacific. The WHO has a critical role to play in the Indo-Pacific and the Prime Minister has highlighted WHO's important work in this region, including in supporting COVID-19 preparedness. Australia has no plans to cease its funding to the WHO.

The COVID-19 pandemic has affected the world like no other health event in living memory, underscoring the need for a concerted global response. Australia will work with all countries to ensure this evaluation delivers outcomes that will help prevent, control and mitigate future health crises. Preventing and responding to global health challenges requires collaboration and engagement with all health authorities. To this end, Australia has consistently supported Taiwan's involvement in the WHO's work. Where statehood is a requirement for membership of organisations, as it is in the WHO, we support Taiwan's participation as an observer or guest.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health, Mr Hunt
Gambling
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your email dated 15 June 2020, on behalf of the Standing Committee on Petitions concerning Petition EN1507 — Banning the use of credit cards for online gambling.
The Morrison Government takes gambling harm to Australians very seriously and recognises the impact of gambling on consumers, their families and communities.

While the implementation of a ban on the use of credit cards to deposit funds into online wagering accounts is not currently within the scope of the Government's reforms, the Government is committed to reducing the harm of problem gambling through its cooperation with state and territory colleagues.

The Government recognises that the average Australian wants to be able to engage in the occasional gambling activity without burdensome regulation, and therefore, our approach is to balance regulations with effective harm reduction measures.
National Consumer Protection Framework

The Commonwealth is continuing to work with the states and territories on implementing the National Consumer Protection Framework for online wagering (National Framework). The National Framework contains 10 key measures aimed at reducing the harm that can be caused by online wagering to consumers.
These measures will provide people with easy-to-use tools and information to better regulate their online gambling, with six of the measures already implemented:
Prohibiting lines of credit being offered by wagering operators;
Discouraging the use of payday lenders for wagering;
Reducing the customer verification period from 90 days to 14 days;
Restricting the use of inducements from wagering providers by prohibiting all specified inducements;
Ensuring that closing/cancelling an online wagering account is readily available, and accessible by all consumers; and
Introducing a voluntary opt-out pre-commitment scheme.
The Government is working to implement the remaining four measures including:
the implementation of activity statements to ensure consumers receive meaningful statements on their wagering activity with each licensed operator;
the development of consistent gambling messaging;
staff training; and
a national self-exclusion register.

On 5 December 2019, the Government passed legislation to enable the establishment of a national self-exclusion register. The register will allow those experiencing gambling harm to immediately exclude themselves from all Australian interactive wagering service services though a single transaction. The Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA) is currently undertaking a procurement process to select an organisation to operate the Register. The Register is expected to be operational by mid-2021.
Government support for people affected by gambling harm
In addition the consumer protections under the National Framework, the Government provides financial counselling to help people, their families and friends affected by problem gambling.

On 29 March 2020, the Government announced a $200 million Community Support Package commencing immediately over two years (from 2019-20 to 2020-21) to support vulnerable Australians impacted by COVID-19. Under this package, $20 million has been provided for financial counselling services and supports, with over $1.8 million to 33 financial counselling services specialising in problem gambling. This is in addition to the funding the Government already provides for financial counsellors to assist persons affected by problem gambling.

In 2019-20, 33 community organisations specialising in problem gambling financial counselling services, delivered support to 7,408 individual and group clients in every state and territory, with a particular focus on areas with high numbers of electronic gaming machines and socio-economic disadvantages. The National Debt Helpline also provides a single contact point for people to access financial counselling, either immediately on the phone or via referral to face-to-face services. Services are voluntary, free and confidential. Across Australia, counselling for gamblers and their families can be accessed by calling the National Gambling Helpline or through Gambling Help Online.
Financial institutions and gambling

Following the 2019 report of the Royal Commission into Misconduct in the Banking, Superannuation and Financial Services Industry, the Government continues to encourage moves by the Australian banking industry to demonstrate strong social leadership in implementing reforms that put in place stronger protections to reduce the harm of gambling to Australians.

Australian financial institutions are able to voluntarily prohibit their credit cards being used for gambling purposes. A number of major financial institutions including Macquarie Bank, American Express and Suncorp, have implemented such a ban. Other financial institutions give their customers the option to restrict or completely block spending on gambling.

The Australian Banking Association (ABA) is considering what good practices can be adopted across the industry to minimise harms from gambling. In December 2019, the ABA released a consultation paper on the use of credit cards for gambling. The ABA consultation paper discusses the issue of gambling and credit cards, and current initiatives by banks to reduce the risks associated with gambling. The ABA envisages the results will help banks as they each consider further reform on the issue.
Protecting Australians from illegal offshore gambling websites

The Government is also working on protecting Australians from illegal offshore gambling services. These services pose a great risk to Australians as they offer minimal to no harm minimisation controls or consumer protections.

On 11 November 2019, the Government announced that ACMA can use its powers to request Australian internal service providers to block illegal offshore gambling websites. As at 28 August 2020, 92 illegal websites have been successfully blocked.

To complement these enforcement actions, ACMA has undertaken an awareness campaign starting to alert Australians on the risks of betting with illegal offshore gambling websites. This campaign is being conducted on social media and digital platforms.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention. I hope the information in this letter is of some help.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Cyber Safety and the Arts, Mr Fletcher
COVID-19
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your letter dated 15 June 2020 to the Prime Minister, the Hon Scott Morrison MP, enclosing petition EN1516, which requests the Commonwealth Government provide a medal for recognition of front line staff responding to the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic. The Prime Minister has asked me to reply on his behalf.

The Prime Minister has acknowledged the response to the crisis has been unprecedented, both on the front-line and behind the scenes. As the Prime Minister said when confirming Australia Day 2021 as a day of thanks for those who have helped our nation through the crisis: "It would be hard to nominate an Australian who in some way large or small has not had their lives impacted, disrupted by the pandemic. It has called on the bigness of Australians and I think that is something we can genuinely give thanks for and to celebrate our resilient character".

Recently Australia has faced harsh challenges — drought, floods, Black Summer bushfires and the unprecedented coronavirus pandemic. For Australia Day 2021 Australians will be encouraged to reflect, respect and celebrate and, more than ever, mark our nation's resilience and the ability of Australians to rise above these and other challenges.

Australia Day 2021 will be a day to reflect, respect and celebrate the contribution all Australians have made in 2020. It will also be an opportunity to celebrate our national heroes. Right now, the priority still remains responding to the COVID-19 crisis. Suitably the focus for the Commonwealth, State and Territory Governments is the health and wellbeing of Australians, their livelihoods, their jobs and ensuring Australia is positioned to emerge strong and robust.

We are working together as Australians do. As the Prime Minister has said "accepting the difficult, accepting the hardship, accepting the disruption and just stoically getting on with it and often reflecting on those who are in a worse situation" is the Australian spirit. We all have a part to play: health workers, employers, employees, governments and everyone with physical distancing.
Thank you for bringing this petition to the Government's attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister and Cabinet, Mr Morton
COVID-19
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence regarding petition EN1525: An independent inquiry into COVID-19.

The first priority of the Australian Government is to safeguard the sovereignty and wellbeing of Australia and its citizens. Our current focus is squarely on getting Australians through COVID-19 — on saving lives and paving the way for economic recovery.

As the health and economic impacts of COVID-19 continue to take a tragic toll across the world, it is imperative Australia continues to champion openness, transparency, and a global rules-based system that supports our national interests. With this in mind, Australia has consistently called for an independent, impartial and comprehensive review into wet markets and the origins of COVID-19 — a call that, on 19 May, received widespread support from the World Health Assembly. We are pleased with the subsequent formation of the Independent Panel for Pandemic Preparedness and Response that will lead the evaluation, and we are pleased the terms of reference for an international mission led by the World Health Organisation have been agreed. The Government is committed to working with the international community, including China, to ensure the review delivers outcomes that will help prevent, control and mitigate future health crises.

As I have stated on numerous occasions, the Government does not countenance economic coercion. The Government continues to stand firmly by this position, just as we continue to do everything we can to protect our exporters and the jobs they support.

Regarding Chinese tourism, the Government was disappointed by the Chinese Foreign Ministry's assertions it is unsafe to visit or study in Australia and there has been a 'significant increase' in racial discrimination and acts of violence against Chinese and Asian people in our country. These assertions are factually incorrect: while there have been some incidents of racism since the COVID-19 pandemic began, these incidents have been isolated and have been dealt with seriously by authorities.

There is also no basis to the suggestion that Australian law enforcement conduct arbitrary searches or property seizures. Australia prides itself as a successful multicultural nation, and we strive to make sure we sit amongst the most inclusive and tolerant countries in the world.

Our relationship with China has never been more important, nor more complex. As two very different countries, Australia and China will experience points of difference, and we must address these differences constructively. This should not, however, take away from the strong mutual complementarities between our two economies. All international trade, including trade with China, will continue to play an important role in Australia's long term recovery from the pandemic.

In 2019, China was Australia's largest and most valuable visitor market, with 1.44 million Chinese travellers spending $12.4 billion - more than a quarter of our total income from inbound international tourism. Some 65 per cent of these were on repeat visits, and we hope they will return again and continue to support Australian businesses after travel restrictions are ultimately lifted. Chinese tourists and students love Australia, and we stand ready to welcome them back just as soon as it becomes safe to do so.

China is the second largest economy in the world and the largest goods market in our region. That is why China will continue to be an important partner for us as we regain our economic strength. Even in the face of a global pandemic, our exports to China have continued to grow and support Australian livelihoods and jobs - particularly in rural and regional Australia, which includes regions that have been among the most affected by the restrictions needed to minimize the spread of COVID-19.
I thank the petitioners for sharing their concerns.
I have sent a copy of this letter to the Minister for Trade, Tourism and Investment, and the Minister for Health.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne
Vaccination
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 24 August 2020 to the Minister for Health, the Hon Greg Hunt MP, concerning Petition number EN1563 requesting the Australian Government to remove the mandatory vaccination regulation to visit nursing homes. Your correspondence has been referred to me as the Minister for Aged Care and Senior Australians with portfolio responsibility for this matter.

States and territories have established directions under their emergency management provisions that set out requirements with regard to visitors to, and entry into, residential aged care facilities. The state and territory directions set out that individuals must not enter or remain on the premises of a residential aged care facility if certain requirements are not met.

The entry restrictions generally apply to most individuals entering a residential aged care facility, including staff, visitors, health practitioners, volunteers and others. There are exemptions on medical grounds (medical contraindications) in place in some jurisdictions. Broadly speaking however there are no exemptions to the influenza vaccination requirements for individuals that choose not to be vaccinated for personal, cultural or religious reasons. Jurisdictions have published supporting information, for individuals to understand how the directions apply to their personal circumstances.
Currently, all jurisdictions except for Victoria have influenza vaccination requirements for individuals seeking to enter a residential aged care facility.

The directions are temporary, established under jurisdictions' emergency management provisions in response to COVID-19. It is a matter for the individual state and territory governments to update and extend the directions in response to the evolving COVID-19 situation.

In relation to the legality of state and territory directions, there is an array of statutory powers that can be exercised in responding to the COVID-19 pandemic. The key statutes which confer these types of powers for use in the current circumstances are powers that are conferred under various Public Health and Biosecurity statutes.

The Government is a strong supporter of immunisation in that it is a safe and effective way to prevent the spread of vaccine preventable diseases, including seasonal influenza. Annual vaccination is the most important measure to prevent influenza and its complications.

While influenza vaccination does not prevent against COVID-19, the influenza vaccination is critical to protecting the general health of Australians from influenza, which can take between 100 to 1,000 lives per year depending on the severity. This year it is even more important to be vigilant about the influenza because of the COVID-19 pandemic. While there is not yet a vaccine or effective treatment for COVID-19, vaccination provides an effective defence against the influenza. Vaccinating against the influenza will reduce the risk of a very dangerous double-up of influenza and coronavirus — both diseases affecting the respiratory system.

The more people who are vaccinated against influenza, the greater the likelihood of reducing the number of people presenting to health providers with influenza-like symptoms. This means that health providers may be better able to identify and manage emerging cases of COVID-19.

Vaccines are only made available in Australia and included on the National Immunisation Program after they have been rigorously tested, evaluated and approved by the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) to ensure they meet stringent safety and efficacy guidelines. Vaccines continue to be tested after their introduction via additional clinical trials, surveillance and monitoring of vaccine adverse events.

Vaccines, like any other medicines can have side effects, however all vaccines used within Australia provide benefits which greatly outweigh their risks. A number of organisations including the Australian Academy of Science, an independent scientific body, have found that vaccinating against diseases is safer and more effective than being infected with those diseases. You may be interested in The Science of Immunisation: Questions and Answers available at: www.science.org.au/education/immunisation-climate-change-genetic¬modification/science-immunisation produced by the Academy of Science.

AusVaxSafety actively monitors vaccine safety throughout Australia and current results are available at: www.ausvaxsafetv.orzau/safetv-data. Parents/carers and immunisation providers can also report adverse events to the TGA via the Adverse Event Management System at: www.tga.gov.au/reporting-adverse-events. The Government's policies on immunisation are based on advice from independent expert clinical advisory groups —the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation and the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee.

Thank you for raising this matter. YoursThank you for your correspondence of 24 August 2020, originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petition ENI587 - Medicare Levy. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

I understand the petitioner's concerns that all Australians should pay their fair share of tax and Medicare levy. In Australia, a resident's income tax liability – for most taxes and for Medicare levy – is based on taxable income, after deductions are taken into account.

A basic principle of the Medicare levy is that it applies to an individual's taxable income from all sources. The fact that taxpayers are required to pay the Medicare levy on taxable Government assistance payments they receive —just as taxpayers are required to pay the Medicare levy on any wage and salary income — is consistent with this basic principle.

However, low-income earners are not liable for the Medicare levy. This is consistent with the progressive nature of income tax, which means those on lower taxable incomes pay less tax. The Medicare levy low-income thresholds ensure that households do not pay Medicare levy if their taxable income is below a certain level, and the amount payable is phased-in over a certain income range. These arrangements ensure that the liability of people to pay the Medicare levy reflects their financial capacity to contribute to the total cost of national health care, and is not merely a payment for service.
The Government considers the current Medicare levy settings to be appropriate. I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Thank you for raising this matter
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Aged Care and Senior Australians, Senator Colbeck
Food Labelling
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 24 August 2020 concerning petition EN1589 received by the Standing Committee on Petitions about implementing an environmental impact rating label for food products..

In 2012, the then Council of Australian Government Legislative and Governance Forum on Food Regulation (now the Australia and New Zealand Ministerial Forum on Food Regulation) agreed to a Food Labelling Policy Conceptual Framework for food regulators to provide a principles-based approach for decision making regarding food labelling. The food labelling hierarchy is based on risk, in descending order of food safety, preventive health and consumer values issues.

The Australia New Zealand Food Standards Code (Code) is aimed at protecting public health and safety. For example, the Code requires ingredient information and a nutrition information panel, which assists consumers to make an informed choice about what is in the food they are purchasing and how it compares with other products. The Code also requires the name of the food to be a name or description that is sufficient to indicate the true nature of the food, and that it be included on the label.

The Code does not include requirements for labelling that relates to people's personal values and ethics, including environmental concerns. However, food suppliers can voluntarily provide this information on the labels of their products, provided the information is not false, misleading or deceptive under consumer and fair trading laws.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health, Mr Hunt
Climate Change
Dear Chair
I refer to your email of 24 August 2020 regarding the Marine Arctic Peace Sanctuary Treaty petition, EN1599.

Australia advocates and seeks to protect an international order in which international law and other rules and norms govern relations between states, including in the context of environmental and marine protection. Responses to climate change are an important influence on international affairs and Australia's economy and I recognise that the world's oceans continue to come under pressure.

We consider proposals intended to protect the world's oceans and Polar Regions carefully against Australia's national interests.
